quizzes.title: Millennial Views – Approaches & Hermeneutics
quizzes.description: Interpretive approaches to Revelation and hermeneutical assumptions behind the millennial views.

questions.question: Which interpretive approach to Revelation sees its symbols as timeless truths rather than predictions tied to a specific historical period?

options.text: Futurist
Historicist
Idealist (symbolic)
Preterist

questions.explanation: Section: Interpretative Approaches to the Book of Revelation. Quote: 'Idealist (or symbolic): the symbols or events it describes will not come to pass in any particular time in history. Rather, they represent timeless truths that are true throughout the church age.'

questions.question: Which interpretive approach understands the events of Revelation as describing the entire age of the church, often seen in seven successive eras?

options.text: Idealist
Historicist
Preterist
Futurist

questions.explanation: Section: Interpretative Approaches. Quote: 'Historicist: the events described occur over the entire age of the church. 7 Churches 7 eras we are in the 7th now.'

questions.question: True or False: The Futurist approach teaches that the events of Revelation primarily occurred in the first century and are now past.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Interpretative Approaches. Futurist is defined as: 'the events described shall occur at the end of the age,' whereas 'Preterist' is associated with prophecies that 'have already been fulfilled.'

questions.question: Which approach views the events of Revelation as already fulfilled at or near the time of its writing?

options.text: Futurist
Preterist
Idealist
Dispensational

questions.explanation: Section: Interpretative Approaches. Quote: 'Preterist: the events described are occurring at the time of writing and the prophecies have already been fulfilled.'

questions.question: True or False: In the notes, premillennialism is associated with a 'normal, grammatical' interpretation of prophecy that distinguishes Israel from the church.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Hermeneutical Assumptions. Quote: 'Normal, (Typical / still not literal) grammatical interpretation of Scripture. Prophecy is to be interpreted consistently. Israel and the Church are not synonyms.'

questions.question: According to the notes, amillennialism and postmillennialism tend to assume which of the following?

options.text: Israel and the Church are distinct peoples with separate promises.
The Kingdom and the Church are synonymous.
Prophecy should always be taken strictly literally.
David’s kingdom is only future, never present.

questions.explanation: Section: Hermeneutical Assumptions – Amillennialism and Postmillennialism. Quote: 'The Kingdom and the Church are assumed to be synonymous.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes criticize the spiritualizing of prophecy in some amillennial and postmillennial interpretations as potentially leading to 'highly fanciful and speculative' readings.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Hermeneutical Assumptions. Quote: 'Prophecy is “spiritualized” in order to transfer the promises from Israel to the Church... This can result in highly fanciful and speculative interpretations.'

questions.question: Which hermeneutical practice is especially associated in the notes with Amillennialism and Postmillennialism, in contrast to Premillennialism?

options.text: Consistently literal reading of prophetic covenants
Spiritualizing Old Testament promises to Israel and applying them to the church
Limiting prophecy only to the first century
Refusing to interpret Revelation symbolically

questions.explanation: Section: Hermeneutical Assumptions – Amillennialism and Postmillennialism. Quote: 'Prophecy is “spiritualized” in order to transfer the promises from Israel to the Church.'

questions.question: According to the notes, what is a key premillennial claim about the promises to Israel?

options.text: They are conditional and have already been forfeited.
They are unconditional and still await literal fulfillment.
They are spiritual only and fulfilled in the church now.
They have been entirely transferred to Gentile nations.

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Hermeneutical Assumptions. Quote: 'The promises to Israel about the nation, land, and King are unconditional and are yet to be fulfilled.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes describe millennialism 'since the sixteenth century' as largely a 'search for certainty in the flow of history.'

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Views of the Kingdom. Quote: 'To a great extent, millennialism since the sixteenth century has been a search for certainty in the flow of history.'

quizzes.title: Millennial Views – Amillennialism
quizzes.description: Definition, tenets, adherents, and critiques of Amillennialism.

questions.question: According to the notes, how does Amillennialism understand the millennium?

options.text: A literal future thousand-year earthly reign of Christ after His return
A symbolic description of the entire present age in which the gospel is preached
A brief period of apostasy immediately preceding Christ’s first coming
A literal thousand-year period in heaven before Christ returns to earth

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Definition. Quote: 'The millennium is symbolic of this whole present age in which the gospel is preached.'

questions.question: True or False: Amillennialism teaches that there will be no future earthly thousand-year reign of Christ.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Definition. Quote: 'There will be no earthly, thousand-year reign of Christ.'

questions.question: Which statement best summarizes the Amillennial view of Christ’s kingdom reign according to the notes?

options.text: Christ’s kingdom is entirely future and begins only at His visible return.
Christ’s kingdom reign is in existence for the period of time between His two advents.
Christ’s kingdom is limited to ethnic Israel in the land of Canaan.
Christ’s kingdom is a short parenthesis between two eternal states.

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The kingdom reign of Christ and His saints is in existence for the period of time between Christ’s two advents (i.e. right now).'

questions.question: In Amillennialism, what is often identified as the kingdom of God in this age?

options.text: The restored national Israel and rebuilt temple
The church on earth and/or the saints in heaven
Only an invisible spiritual kingdom with no relation to the church
The political nations that adopt biblical law

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The kingdom is either the church on earth (Augustinian/Roman Catholic view) and/or the saints in heaven (Warfield).'

questions.question: True or False: In the notes, Amillennialism claims that God’s promises to Israel about land, seed, and throne are fulfilled now in a spiritual sense in the church.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The promises to Israel about a land, seed, and throne are thus completely fulfilled now in a spiritual sense in the church.'

questions.question: According to the Amillennial tenets, why have the promises to Israel been transferred to the church?

options.text: Because the covenants were always conditional upon circumcision alone.
Because Israel did not meet the condition of obedience.
Because God abolished all national distinctions in Genesis 12.
Because the New Testament explicitly denies any future for Israel.

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'God’s promises to Israel were conditional and have been transferred to the church because the nation did not meet the condition of obedience.'

questions.question: True or False: In Amillennialism, Christ is presently seated on the throne of David and Satan is considered presently bound between Christ’s two advents.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'Christ is ruling now in heaven where He is seated on the throne of David, and Satan is presently bound between Christ’s two advents.'

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the critiques listed in the notes against Amillennialism’s handling of messianic prophecies?

options.text: It takes Psalm 22 and Isaiah 53 too literally.
It spiritualizes messianic prophecies that the New Testament treats literally.
It denies the existence of any messianic prophecies in the Old Testament.
It insists on only future fulfillment and never sees present application.

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Critique. Quote: 'The New Testament does not spiritualize messianic prophecies. Passages such as Ps. 22, Micah 5:2, and Isa. 53 are understood to be fulfilled literally.'

questions.question: According to the critique in the notes, equating 'true Israel' with the church is difficult to reconcile with which New Testament section?

options.text: Matthew 5–7
Romans 9–11
Hebrews 11
Revelation 20

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Critique. Quote: 'Equating true Israel with the Church is difficult to reconcile with Rom. 9-11.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes say that, historically, Amillennialism has been the predominant view only in the twentieth century among evangelicals.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Adherents. Quote: 'Though premillennialism is the predominant view today, the pre-eminent position over the majority of Christian history is amillennialism.'

quizzes.title: Millennial Views – Postmillennialism
quizzes.description: Definition, tenets, Scriptural arguments, adherents, and critiques of Postmillennialism.

questions.question: According to the notes, how does Postmillennialism expect the gospel to impact the world before Christ’s return?

options.text: It will save only a small remnant in each generation.
It will win the vast majority of human beings to salvation in the present age.
It will primarily harden the nations rather than convert them.
It will have no significant visible impact until after Christ returns.

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Definition. Quote: 'Postmillennialism expects the proclaiming of the Spirit-blessed gospel of Jesus Christ to win the vast majority of human beings to salvation in the present age.'

questions.question: True or False: Postmillennialism anticipates a long period in history before Christ’s return in which faith, righteousness, peace, and prosperity broadly prevail.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Definition. Quote: 'Increasing gospel success will gradually produce a time in history prior to Christ’s return in which faith, righteousness, peace, and prosperity prevail in the affairs of people and of nations.'

questions.question: Which of the following figures is listed among the notable postmillennial adherents in the notes?

options.text: Karl Barth
Jonathan Edwards
Martin Luther
Wayne Grudem

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Adherents. Quote: 'Adherents: Daniel Whitby..., Jonathan Edwards..., William Carey..., B. H. Carroll..., George W. Truett..., Iain Murray, and Kenneth Gentry, Lottie Moon.'

questions.question: Postmillennialism views the Kingdom of God in this age primarily as:

options.text: A purely future heavenly reality only
Primarily a present earthly reality growing through the spread of the gospel
Limited entirely to Old Testament Israel
A brief, hidden parenthesis in redemptive history

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The Kingdom of God is primarily a present reality; it is here in earthly fashion... The King of God will grow gradually through the continuing spread of the Gospel.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes say Postmillennialism expects the conversion of all the nations prior to Christ’s return.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The conversion of all the nations prior to Christ’s return is expected.'

questions.question: Which of the following is one critique raised against Postmillennialism in the notes?

options.text: It has no Scriptural basis for a general resurrection.
The claim that the world is getting better morally and spiritually is questionable at best.
It denies that Christ will ever return bodily.
It insists the millennium must be a literal 1,000 years.

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Critique. Quote: 'The assertion that the world is getting better morally and spiritually is questionable, at best.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes argue that Postmillennialism often neglects Scriptures that speak of worsening spiritual and moral conditions before the end.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Critique. Quote: 'Postmillennialists seem to neglect the Scriptures that speak of the spiritual and moral condition of the world worsening in the end times (Matt. 24:9-14).'

questions.question: According to Doyle’s critique cited in the notes, why does Postmillennialism fail?

options.text: Because it denies the resurrection of the body.
Because it links world restoration to a secret rapture of the church.
Because it fails to link world restoration to the revealing of the children of God at the resurrection.
Because it rejects all Old Testament prophecies as non-Christian.

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Critique. Quote: 'Postmillennialism fails because the New Testament links the restoration of the world, the removal of creation’s futility, to “the revealing of the children of God,” that is, “the redemption of our bodies” at the resurrection (Rom. 8:18-25).'

questions.question: True or False: The notes distinguish conservative Postmillennialists from American Protestant liberalism and secular progressivism, even though some themes overlap.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Adherents. Quote: 'A secularized version of postmillennialism lied behind certain types of 19th and 20th century progressivism... Conservative postmillennialists, however, have taken pains to distance themselves from both.'

questions.question: Which Old Testament passages are cited in the notes as promising a universal time of peace and righteousness that Postmillennialists appeal to?

options.text: Isaiah 2:1–4 and Isaiah 45:22–25
Psalm 1 and Psalm 2
Daniel 2 and Daniel 7
Micah 4 and Amos 9

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Scriptural Arguments. Quote: 'The Old Testament Prophets promise a universal time of peace and righteousness (Isa. 2:1-4; 45:22-25).'

quizzes.title: Millennial Views – Premillennialism
quizzes.description: Definition, tenets, Scriptural arguments, and critiques of Premillennialism.

questions.question: According to the notes, what is the basic definition of Premillennialism?

options.text: Christ returns after a long golden age of gospel prosperity and then ends history immediately.
After Jesus comes, He will establish and rule over a kingdom on this earth for a millennium.
Christ’s reign is only spiritual and heavenly, with no earthly manifestation.
The millennium is purely symbolic of individual regeneration.

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Definition. Quote: 'This is the belief that after Jesus comes, he will establish and rule over a kingdom on this earth for a millennium, that is, for a thousand years.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes say premillennialism was the dominant view of the early church.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Adherents. Quote: 'Premillennialism was the dominant view of the early church and was held by Clement, Polycarp, Papias, Justin Martyr, Irenaeus, and Tertullian, to name a few.'

questions.question: Which of the following is listed as a key tenet of Premillennialism?

options.text: The present age will gradually improve until evil disappears before Christ returns.
The end of the present age will be characterized by great apostasy and culminate in a time of judgment called the Tribulation.
The millennium is already fully realized in the church today.
The promises to Israel are entirely fulfilled in the first coming of Christ.

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The end of the present age with be characterized by a great apostasy and will culminate in a time of judgment called the Tribulation.'

questions.question: Premillennialism understands the two resurrections in Revelation 20:4–6 as:

options.text: Two symbolic stages of spiritual regeneration only.
A spiritual first resurrection and a bodily second resurrection.
Both resurrections bodily in nature, separated by the millennium.
A resurrection of Christ and later a resurrection of angels only.

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The two resurrections mentioned in Rev. 20:4-6 are both bodily in nature.'

questions.question: True or False: Premillennialism holds that the promises made to ethnic Israel about land, temple, and spiritual conversion will NOT be fulfilled literally in the future.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The promises made to ethnic Israel concerning the return to the promised land, the rebuilt temple, and an eventual spiritual conversion will all be fulfilled literally in the future.'

questions.question: According to the notes, the covenants that include the promise of an earthly kingdom and support Premillennialism are:

options.text: Noahic, Mosaic, and Priestly
Abrahamic, Davidic, and New Covenant
Adamic, Mosaic, and Abrahamic
Levitical, Priestly, and Davidic only

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Arguments. Quote: 'The covenants that God made with Israel include the promise of an earthly kingdom (Abrahamic—Gen. 15:18-21; Davidic—2 Sam. 7:4-16; and New Covenant—Jer. 31:31-34).'

questions.question: True or False: One critique of Premillennialism in the notes is that an earthly millennium seems theologically superfluous, since one might expect history to move directly into the new heavens and new earth at Christ’s return.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Critique. Quote: 'An earthly millennium appears to be theologically superfluous. At the return of Christ, why not move directly into the ultimate state of the new heavens and the new earth?'

questions.question: Which concern is raised in the notes about whether dispensational Premillennialism might be repeating certain 'hermeneutical errors' of first-century Judaism?

options.text: Over-emphasizing the spiritual nature of the kingdom
Interpreting messianic prophecies as applying only to Gentiles
Viewing the kingdom too much in military and nationalistic terms
Denying that David’s throne continues in any sense today

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Critique. The notes ask whether dispensationalists are 'making the same hermeneutical errors that misled 1st century Judaism' and mention that this question 'implies that premillennialism has a flavor that is too Jewish,' often seen as overly political or military.

questions.question: True or False: The notes indicate that Revelation 20 is the only passage in Scripture that explicitly mentions a thousand-year reign.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Critique. Quote: 'Rev. 20 is the only passage in the Scriptures that explicitly mentions a thousand year reign.'

questions.question: In the notes, what overarching redemptive storyline is mentioned in connection with evaluating an earthly millennium?

options.text: Creation–Fall–Law–Temple–Silence
Creation–Exodus–Monarchy–Exile
Creation–Fall–Redemption–Consummation
Law–Prophets–Writings–Gospels

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Critique. The notes remark: 'We have this grand narrative creation, fall, redemption, consummation,' raising the question of where a separate earthly millennium fits.

quizzes.title: Millennial Views – Comparative Review
quizzes.description: Mixed comparative questions on Amillennialism, Postmillennialism, and Premillennialism.

questions.question: Which view interprets Revelation 20:1–6 as describing the souls of dead believers reigning with Christ in heaven rather than an earthly millennium?

options.text: Premillennialism
Amillennialism
Postmillennialism
Futurist Idealism

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Definition. Quote: 'Revelation 20:1-6 is a description of the souls of dead believers reigning with Christ in heaven.'

questions.question: True or False: In the notes, both Amillennialism and Postmillennialism typically identify the Kingdom of God with the Church, whereas Premillennialism makes a sharper distinction between Israel and the Church.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Hermeneutical Assumptions. Amillennialism/Postmillennialism: 'The Kingdom and the Church are assumed to be synonymous.' Premillennialism: 'Israel and the Church are not synonyms.'

questions.question: Which view most clearly expects a historically observable 'golden age' of Christianized culture prior to Christ’s return?

options.text: Amillennialism
Premillennialism
Postmillennialism
Hyper-Preterism

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Definition and Tenets. It anticipates a time 'in which faith, righteousness, peace, and prosperity prevail' prior to Christ’s visible return.

questions.question: True or False: According to the notes, Premillennialism sees the millennium as the fulfillment of Old Testament promises to Israel about a glorious kingdom.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The millennium is the fulfillment of the Old Testament promises to Israel about a glorious kingdom.'

questions.question: Which view is explicitly said to regard 'thousand' in Revelation 20 as a symbolic number indicating a long period of time rather than a precise duration?

options.text: Premillennialism
Amillennialism
Postmillennialism
Preterism

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The word “thousand” is a symbolic number indicating a long period of time.'

questions.question: Which of the following best matches Premillennialism’s expectation for the moral and spiritual trend of the world near the end of the age, according to its tenets?

options.text: Ongoing moral improvement without major apostasy
A great apostasy culminating in the Tribulation
A neutral plateau with neither progress nor decline
An already completed Tribulation in the first century

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'The end of the present age with be characterized by a great apostasy and will culminate in a time of judgment called the Tribulation.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes argue that the optimism of certain Scriptural Kingdom promises appears contingent on the physical presence of the King, which raises questions for Postmillennialism’s expectation of a golden age before Christ’s return.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Critique. The notes state: 'The optimism expressed in the Scriptures about the world experiencing Kingdom blessings and righteousness seems to be contingent on the physical presence of the King.'

questions.question: Which view is said in the notes to have been the predominant view among evangelicals in the twentieth century, particularly among Southern Baptists?

options.text: Amillennialism
Postmillennialism
Premillennialism
Full Preterism

questions.explanation: Section: Premillennialism – Adherents. Quote: 'In the 20th century, premillennialism has been the predominant view among evangelicals in general and Southern Baptists in particular.'

questions.question: Which view most straightforwardly claims that Satan is presently bound between Christ’s two advents, according to the tenets cited?

options.text: Premillennialism
Postmillennialism
Amillennialism
Hyper-Preterism

questions.explanation: Section: Amillennialism – Tenets. Quote: 'Christ is ruling now in heaven where He is seated on the throne of David, and Satan is presently bound between Christ’s two advents.'

questions.question: True or False: According to the notes, Postmillennialism was the dominant position among American evangelicals in the late eighteenth century and much of the nineteenth century.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Section: Postmillennialism – Adherents. Quote: 'Postmillennialism “was the dominant position among American evangelicals in the late eighteenth century and throughout most of the nineteenth century.” (Grenz:1992, 66)'

quizzes.title: Election – Big Picture & Calvinist Structures
quizzes.description: Twin biblical truths, distinction between predestination and election, and the basic Calvinist frameworks.

questions.question: According to the notes, which pair of statements best summarizes the 'twin biblical truths' about evil and salvation?

options.text: God created a world in which evil and sin are possible, and God will eventually save all people without exception.
God created a world in which evil and sin are possible, and God did not create a world in which all will receive forgiveness.
God created a world in which evil and sin are necessary, and God created a world in which some will be forgiven by their own merit.
God did not create a world in which evil is possible, and only those who perfectly obey escape judgment.

questions.explanation: The introduction to Election lists two 'twin biblical truths': (1) God created a world in which evil and sin are possible; (2) God did not create a world in which all will receive forgiveness for their evil and sin.

questions.question: True or False: The notes say that Universalists deny the second of the twin biblical truths and thereby remove the 'sting' of the first.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The introduction explicitly notes that Universalists deny the truth that not all will receive forgiveness, and thus 'remove the sting (and the significance) of the first.'

questions.question: In the notes, 'predestination' is distinguished from 'election.' Which description correctly reflects that distinction?

options.text: Predestination concerns salvation only, while election concerns everything else.
Predestination refers to God’s universal plan for all things, while election focuses specifically on salvation.
Predestination and election are identical terms and should never be distinguished.
Predestination refers to human choices, while election refers to angelic choices.

questions.explanation: The notes state that theologians 'generally distinguish predestination (universal plan) from election (salvation). The former refers to God’s universal plan; the latter focuses on salvation.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes present Calvinism, Amyraldianism, Arminianism, and Molinism as four approaches to predestination and election to salvation.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Immediately after defining predestination and election, the notes say: 'We will survey four approaches: Calvinism, Amyraldianism, Arminianism, and Molinism.'

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the basic difference between Supralapsarianism and Infralapsarianism within Calvinism as presented in the notes?

options.text: They differ mainly on the extent of human free will after conversion.
They differ on whether God’s decree to elect and reprobate logically comes before or after His decree to permit the Fall.
They differ on whether Christ’s atonement is substitutionary or governmental.
They differ on whether foreknowledge or middle knowledge grounds election.

questions.explanation: The notes introduce Supralapsarianism ('High Calvinism') and Infralapsarianism as differing in the order of the divine decrees, especially in relation to the Fall.

questions.question: True or False: Supralapsarianism is presented in the notes as the majority position within Calvinism today.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes describe Supralapsarianism as a 'minority view within Calvinism today,' even though it was 'the position of the original Reformers and several at the Synod of Dort.'

questions.question: Which of the following best describes 'double predestination' as used for Supralapsarianism in the notes?

options.text: God predestines only the elect while the reprobate remain outside His decrees.
God simultaneously decrees both the salvation of some and the damnation of others as parallel aspects of His plan.
God decrees to save all people but predestines the timing of their salvation differently.
God decrees only that some will hear the gospel twice rather than once.

questions.explanation: In the Supralapsarian list of decrees, God first decrees 'To save some and condemn others' and the notes label this framework 'Double predestination.'

questions.question: Which of the following best fits the description of Infralapsarianism in the notes?

options.text: It emphasizes a symmetrical relationship between God’s dealings with the elect and the reprobate.
It makes much of the concept of permission and argues for passive reprobation.
It denies a distinction between God’s revealed and secret will.
It asserts that the gospel is not truly offered to any non-elect person.

questions.explanation: The Infralapsarian description says it 'makes much use of the concept of “permission”' and 'argues for passive reprobation,' where the reprobate 'are not ordained for hell but are omitted from heaven.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes state that Supralapsarianism has fewer moral problems while Infralapsarianism attempts to have fewer logical problems.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes say: 'Supralapsarianism has fewer logical problems while infralapsarianism attempts to have few moral problems.'

questions.question: Which term is used in the notes to describe the Reformed attempt to distinguish between what God reveals and what He secretly wills, especially in Infralapsarianism?

options.text: Antecedent vs. Consequent will
Natural vs. Free will
Revealed will vs. Secret will
Permissive will vs. Non-permissive will

questions.explanation: The Infralapsarian section says it 'argues for a distinction between God’s revealed will and his secret will.'

quizzes.title: Election – Supralapsarianism in Detail
quizzes.description: Decrees, description, and consequences of Supralapsarian 'High Calvinism'.

questions.question: In Supralapsarianism, which decree comes first in the logical order presented in the notes?

options.text: To create human beings.
To permit the Fall.
To save some and condemn others.
To provide salvation only for the elect.

questions.explanation: The Supralapsarian list of decrees begins with: 'To save some and condemn others.'

questions.question: True or False: In Supralapsarianism, God’s decree to create both the elect and the reprobate follows His decree to save some and condemn others.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes list 'To save some and condemn others' and then 'To create both the elect (love) and the reprobate (hate).' Creation follows the decree to save/condemn.

questions.question: Which of the following is explicitly said about Supralapsarianism’s view of God’s relationship to evil in the notes?

options.text: It denies that God has any relation whatsoever to evil.
It cautiously avoids attributing the origin of evil to God in any way.
It clearly understands God to be the cause of all things, including evil.
It claims Satan is sovereign over evil without reference to God’s decree.

questions.explanation: The Supralapsarian description says: 'Clearly understands God to be the cause of all things, including evil. ... Does not hesitate to make God the author of evil.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes say Supralapsarianism emphasizes a symmetrical relationship between God’s dealings with the elect and with the reprobate.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The description of Supralapsarianism says it has a 'Symmetrical relationship between God and both classes of people.'

questions.question: According to the Supralapsarian view quoted by Engelsma, what does 'reprobation' assert about God’s attitude toward some people?

options.text: That God eternally loves all men in exactly the same way.
That God is neutral toward the reprobate and simply permits their damnation.
That God eternally hates some men and immutably decrees their damnation.
That God desires to save all equally but is unable to do so.

questions.explanation: Engelsma’s quote: 'Reprobation asserts that God eternally hates some men; has immutably decreed their damnation; and has determined to withhold from them Christ, grace, faith, and salvation.'

questions.question: True or False: According to the notes, Supralapsarianism denies that the gospel is genuinely offered to all and views preaching not as an offer but as an instrument to activate faith in the elect.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes say: 'Denies that the Gospel genuinely is offered to all. In fact, the Gospel is not offered at all, but proclaimed. Preaching is not seen as an offer of salvation, but rather the instrument by which faith is activated.'

questions.question: Which of the following is listed as a possible outcome of Supralapsarian logic for some thinkers, according to the notes?

options.text: Open theism
Universalism (e.g., Barth and the 'No Hellers')
Pelagianism
Modalism

questions.explanation: The notes state: 'At this point, some Supras opt for Universalism (e.g., Karl Barth and the “No Hellers”).'

questions.question: The notes state that in Supralapsarianism, God’s hatred for the reprobate is viewed in what way relative to His love?

options.text: As a lesser, secondary attribute.
As a temporary attitude that will eventually be replaced by love.
As an attribute equal to His love.
As nonexistent; hatred is not attributed to God in any sense.

questions.explanation: The summary says Supralapsarianism 'Makes God’s hatred for the reprobate an attribute equal to his love.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes indicate that Supralapsarianism argues strongly from the infinite attributes of God and sees all things as the working out of the first decree.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The description: 'Argued strongly from the infinite attributes of God... Understands all things to be the working out of the first decree, including the subsequent three decrees.'

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the stated Supralapsarian decrees in the notes?

options.text: To save some and condemn others.
To create both the elect and the reprobate.
To orchestrate the Fall of both classes.
To provide salvation potentially for all and then choose some to receive it.

questions.explanation: The Supralapsarian decrees end with 'To provide salvation only for the elect.' Providing salvation potentially for all and then choosing some is characteristic of Amyraldianism, not of Supralapsarianism.

quizzes.title: Election – Infralapsarianism & Amyraldianism
quizzes.description: Decrees, asymmetry, permission, and the 4-point Calvinist variant.

questions.question: In Infralapsarianism, which decree logically comes first according to the notes?

options.text: To save some and condemn others.
To provide salvation sufficient for all.
To create human beings.
To elect according to foreknowledge.

questions.explanation: The Infralapsarian decrees begin: 'To create human beings.'

questions.question: True or False: In Infralapsarianism, the Fall is something God actively causes in exactly the same way He saves the elect.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Infralapsarianism lists the second decree as 'To permit the Fall,' and makes much of permission; it does not say God causes the Fall in the same way He saves.

questions.question: Which phrase best describes Infralapsarianism’s view of reprobation in the notes?

options.text: Active reprobation identical in form to election.
Passive reprobation in which the reprobate are omitted from heaven rather than directly ordained to hell.
Universal reprobation with no election at all.
Conditional reprobation based on foreseen unbelief alone.

questions.explanation: The notes say Infralapsarianism 'Argues for passive reprobation. The reprobate are not ordained for hell but are omitted from heaven.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes suggest that Infralapsarianism attempts to reduce moral difficulties, whereas Supralapsarianism has fewer logical problems.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The comparison line says: 'Supralapsarianism has fewer logical problems while infralapsarianism attempts to have few moral problems.'

questions.question: In Amyraldianism, often called 4-point Calvinism, which sequence of decrees is given in the notes?

options.text: Create human beings; elect some; permit the Fall; provide salvation for the elect only.
Permit the Fall; create human beings; provide salvation sufficient for all; elect some.
Create human beings; permit the Fall; provide salvation sufficient for all; choose some to receive this salvation.
Create human beings; elect all; permit the Fall; remove grace from some.

questions.explanation: The Amyraldian decrees are listed: 'To create human beings. To permit the Fall. To provide salvation sufficient for all. To choose some to receive this salvation.'

questions.question: True or False: Amyraldianism holds to limited atonement in exactly the same way as classic 5-point Calvinism.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Amyraldianism is described as 'unlimited atonement with a limited application'—sufficient for all, efficient only for the elect.

questions.question: According to the notes, where did Moïse Amyraut believe we should begin our theological reflection in order to avoid a 'fatal labyrinth'?

options.text: With the eternal decree of election considered in isolation.
With the economy of salvation in history, especially the work of Christ.
With the free will of man as an autonomous starting point.
With the hidden will of God apart from revelation.

questions.explanation: Amyraut argued 'We must begin with Christ' and insisted that we must let the 'economy of salvation (presented in history) guide our investigations,' rather than beginning with abstract decrees.

questions.question: True or False: Amyraldianism, as presented in the notes, views election as a decision primarily located in the economic work of the Holy Spirit, while the Father and Son have a more universal scope.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes say Amyraut sees 'a universal will in the Father, a universal work in the Son, but a limited work of the Spirit,' and that election is 'a decision of the Holy Spirit.'

questions.question: Which of the following best characterizes Amyraldianism’s relation to Infralapsarianism regarding grace?

options.text: It rejects effectual grace altogether.
It holds essentially the same position as Infralapsarianism regarding effectual grace and retains the same problems.
It adopts Arminian prevenient grace but keeps limited atonement.
It teaches that all grace is merely common and never saving.

questions.explanation: The notes: 'Holds to the same position as Infra- concerning effectual grace and retains all the same problems as Infra.'

questions.question: True or False: Amyraldianism is described as 'Sublapsarianism' in the sense that the Fall is permitted before the decree to provide salvation sufficient for all.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes call Amyraldianism 'Sublapsarianism—unlimited atonement with a limited application,' and the decree order is: create, permit the Fall, then provide salvation sufficient for all.

quizzes.title: Election – Arminianism & Thiessen’s Structure
quizzes.description: Conditional election, foreknowledge, prevenient grace, and Thiessen’s argument.

questions.question: Which sequence of decrees is given in the notes for Arminianism?

options.text: To provide Christ for the elect; to save them irresistibly; to damn those not chosen; to give common grace to all.
To provide Christ as Savior for all; to save those who believe and damn those who do not; to provide sufficient grace for all; to elect and damn particular individuals according to foreknowledge.
To elect some unconditionally; to provide Christ only for them; to regenerate them before faith; to leave others in their sin.
To create; to permit the Fall; to provide salvation sufficient for all; to choose some to receive it.

questions.explanation: The Arminian decrees in the notes: 'To provide Christ as Savior for all. To save those who believe and damn those who do not. To provide sufficient grace for all to believe. To elect and damn particular individuals according to foreknowledge.'

questions.question: True or False: In Arminianism as described in the notes, election is understood to be entirely corporate and never involves God’s choice of particular individuals.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes say election is 'entirely corporate in nature, while God’s choice of the individual is based entirely on his foreknowledge of a person’s choice.' Both corporate and individual are in view.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key presupposition in Thiessen’s argument for election according to foreknowledge?

options.text: God is the efficient cause of moral evil.
Humans are not responsible moral agents.
God is not the author of sin and must take the initiative in salvation.
God’s decrees are based on caprice and arbitrary will.

questions.explanation: Thiessen’s starting presuppositions include: 'God is not the Author of sin' and 'God is the Initiator and Accomplisher of salvation (God must take the first step),' and that humans are moral agents and God’s decrees are not capricious.

questions.question: True or False: In Thiessen’s view, God’s decree 'to permit sin' makes God the efficient cause of moral evil.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Thiessen explicitly says: 'To permit sin: God is not the efficient cause of moral evil... Sin is permitted and not necessitated.'

questions.question: Which of the following best describes 'prevenient grace' in the Arminian/Thiessen framework presented in the notes?

options.text: A grace given only to the elect that irresistibly brings them to faith.
A common grace that merely damns by increasing knowledge without enabling response.
A grace that restores to every sinner the ability to make a favorable response to God, making salvation possible for all.
A mystical experience granted only after a long period of sanctification.

questions.explanation: Thiessen argues that God's grace 'also restores to the sinner the ability to make a favorable response to God... we hold that God, in His grace, makes it possible for all men to be saved.'

questions.question: True or False: Thiessen insists that the common grace of God is intended merely to damn by giving people enough knowledge to be guilty but not enough to be saved.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Thiessen rejects that view, quoting Moody’s challenge: 'What kind of God is he who gives man enough knowledge to damn him but not enough to save him?' He sees grace as intended to induce people to respond.

questions.question: In Thiessen’s scheme, how is election described with respect to foreknowledge and merit?

options.text: It is based strictly on human merit and not on foreknowledge at all.
It is based on foreknowledge of how people will respond to prevenient grace, yet it is still gracious and does not rest on human merit.
It is entirely unrelated to any view of human response, whether meritorious or not.
It is based on God’s ignorance of future free actions.

questions.explanation: Thiessen says election is 'based on foreknowledge' (Rom 8:29; 1 Pet 1:1–2) and is gracious—'unconditional in the sense that it does not rest on human merit,' even though it is linked to foreknown response to grace.

questions.question: True or False: The notes affirm that conservative Arminians (like Wesley) argue for something 'close to Pelagianism' and therefore deny the need for prevenient grace.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes contrast 'liberal Arminians' as close to Pelagianism, while 'conservative Arminians (John Wesley, for example) argue for prevenient grace.'

questions.question: According to the critique in the notes, what does Arminianism 'fail to fully appreciate' about God’s decree?

options.text: God’s unconditional decree to create both believers and non-believers.
The role of Christ’s atonement in redemption.
The seriousness of human sin.
The need for good works after conversion.

questions.explanation: The critique says Arminianism 'fails to fully appreciate God’s unconditional decree to create both believers and non-believers,' and thus turns election into mere divine acquiescence.

questions.question: True or False: Spurgeon’s critique, quoted in the notes, accuses Arminianism of making Christ marry a bride that He Himself did not choose.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes quote Spurgeon: 'Arminianism marries Christ to a bride he did not choose.'

quizzes.title: Election – Molinism & Middle Knowledge
quizzes.description: Natural, middle, and free knowledge; Molinist election; advantages and objections.

questions.question: According to the notes, Molinism differs from other models of election by focusing primarily on what aspect of God?

options.text: God’s omnipotence as sheer determining power.
God’s omniscience, including His knowledge of counterfactuals (what could be).
God’s ignorance of future contingents.
God’s passivity in relation to human free choices.

questions.explanation: Molinism is defined as God accomplishing His will 'primarily by means of his omniscience, including his knowledge of counterfactuals (what could be).'

questions.question: True or False: In Molinism, 'natural knowledge' refers to God’s knowledge of all contingent truths in the actual world after He decrees to create it.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes define natural knowledge as God’s knowledge of all necessary truths. Knowledge of all contingent truths of this world belongs to His 'free knowledge.'

questions.question: Which of the following correctly matches 'middle knowledge' in the Molinist framework?

options.text: Knowledge of all necessary truths.
Knowledge of all contingent truths of this actual world after God’s decree.
Knowledge of all contingent truths of every possible world (what free creatures would do in any circumstance).
Knowledge of only past and present events, not future contingents.

questions.explanation: The notes: 'God’s middle knowledge: all contingent truths of every possible world... Would have been true of every possible world.'

questions.question: True or False: According to William Lane Craig’s quoted summary, in Molinism it is up to God which possible world we find ourselves in, but up to us whether we are predestined in that world by our response to His grace.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Craig is quoted: 'It is up to God whether we find ourselves in a world in which we are predestined, but it is up to us whether we are predestined in the world in which we find ourselves.'

questions.question: In the Molinist model, how is God’s universal salvific will (His desire that all be saved) upheld differently than in Calvinism according to the notes?

options.text: Molinism denies that God desires all to be saved.
Molinism can affirm without qualification that God is 'not willing that any should perish' while still affirming a particular election based on world choice.
Molinism teaches that God’s will to save all is purely hypothetical and never actually operative.
Molinism rejects texts like John 3:16 and 2 Peter 3:9 as non-literal.

questions.explanation: The notes say Molinism 'affirms the genuine desire on the part of God for all to be saved' and that the Molinist can affirm texts like 2 Pet 3:9 without qualification while still holding to particular election through world choice.

questions.question: True or False: Molinism teaches that the reprobate exist and are lost because God actively causes their unbelief, in the same way He causes the elect to believe.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes clarify: 'Why does the reprobate exist? Because of God’s sovereign will. Why is he reprobated? Because of his own unbelief.' God renders certain, but does not cause, their destruction.

questions.question: Which of the following is listed as an advantage of Molinism over Arminianism in the notes?

options.text: Molinism denies that God actively elects certain individuals.
Molinism can say God is the author of salvation who actively elects certain ones, using exhaustive foreknowledge in a sovereign way.
Molinism avoids any talk of divine foreknowledge.
Molinism claims that creation and election are purely random acts of God.

questions.explanation: The notes say: 'In the Molinist system, unlike Arminianism, God is the author of salvation who actively elects certain ones... God uses His exhaustive foreknowledge in an active, sovereign way.'

questions.question: True or False: The 'grounding objection' against Molinism questions how God can infallibly know what free creatures would do in circumstances that never actually occur.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes mention that critics contend Molinism 'fails to give an adequate explanation of how God infallibly knows what choices free creatures are going to make (the grounding objection).' This concerns counterfactual knowledge.

questions.question: According to the notes, where does Molinism 'place mystery' in contrast to Calvinism?

options.text: In God’s holy character, suggesting ambiguity about His goodness.
In God’s infinite attributes (such as omniscience), rather than in His character.
In human responsibility rather than divine action.
In Scripture itself, claiming it is unclear.

questions.explanation: The notes: 'Molinism places mystery where it should be located, i.e. in God’s infinite attributes rather than in his character.' Calvinism, by contrast, must struggle not to make God the author of sin.

questions.question: True or False: The notes claim that Molinism has a 'valid concept of permission' that is not merely a softer synonym for causation, unlike some Reformed uses of 'permit.'

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes argue that in Molinism, 'permit means “permit,”' and contrast this with some Reformed theologians who effectively treat permission as a 'form of causation.'

quizzes.title: Election – The Call to Salvation & Models of Grace
quizzes.description: Types of call, hyper-Calvinism, Reformed call, Arminian prevenient grace, and overcoming grace.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four types of 'call' identified in the notes?

options.text: Naming of persons, places, or things.
Summons to service, ministry, or a task.
Corporate call to privilege.
Call to economic prosperity and political influence.

questions.explanation: The four types are: naming, summons to service, corporate call to privilege, and invitation to repentance and salvation. A call to economic prosperity/political influence is not listed.

questions.question: True or False: In Hyper-Calvinism, as described in the notes, there is no general call of the gospel to all people and no duty for all to repent and believe.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The Gospel Standard Articles quoted deny 'duty faith and duty repentance' and 'deny offers of grace; that is to say, that the gospel is to be offered indiscriminately to all.'

questions.question: In the 'outward universal; inward particular' view (Calvinist and Amyraldian), how is God’s will often described?

options.text: As a single will that always desires and achieves the salvation of all.
As entirely unknown and never revealed.
As having a revealed will that desires all to be saved and a secret will that saves only the elect.
As having an antecedent will to damn all and a consequent will to save some.

questions.explanation: The notes: 'Outward universal call; Inward particular call to the elect: God has two wills: a revealed will that all are saved, but a secret will that only the elect are saved.'

questions.question: True or False: The notes criticize the hidden/revealed wills approach partly because it can make the preacher’s universal gospel offer seem hypocritical or fraudulent.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes quote critics like Engelsma who argue that preaching universal love and atonement while 'whispering' that God does not intend to save all makes the message 'a fraud.'

questions.question: In the Arminian/Thiessen view of calling, God’s will is often described using which pair of categories?

options.text: Decretive vs. permissive will
Antecedent vs. consequent will
Prescriptive vs. descriptive will
General vs. special will

questions.explanation: The section on 'Universal, prevenient work of grace to all' says Arminian, Greek Orthodox, and many Roman Catholics speak of God having 'two wills—Antecedent and Consequent.'

questions.question: True or False: In the Arminian-prevenient grace model, God’s grace restores enough freedom so that sinners can make a genuinely favorable response to the gospel.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Thiessen argues that common/prevenient grace 'restores to the sinner the ability to make a favorable response to God' so that 'God, in His grace, makes it possible for all men to be saved.'

questions.question: In the 'overcoming grace' model described in the notes, how is the relationship between God’s grace and human faith portrayed?

options.text: Faith is a gift that is irresistible and therefore cannot be resisted by anyone to whom it is given.
Faith is entirely a human achievement independent of grace.
Faith is indeed a gift from God, but this does not entail that it is irresistible; grace can be resisted.
Faith is irrelevant to salvation in this model.

questions.explanation: The 'overcoming grace' section says: 'Faith is indeed a gift from God, but this does not entail that it is irresistible... The Bible teaches that God and his grace can be resisted.'

questions.question: True or False: The 'overcoming grace' model is consistent with a 'well-meant' offer of the gospel and emphasizes that if the word 'offer' has any real meaning, then the gospel is truly available when offered.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes explicitly say that this model 'is consistent with a “well-meant” offer of the Gospel' and note that 'if the word “offer” has any real meaning, then when the Gospel is offered, it really is available.'

questions.question: According to the conclusion on the divine call, which statement best summarizes the relationship between salvation, damnation, and responsibility in the view highlighted by Spurgeon?

options.text: Salvation and damnation are both ultimately God’s responsibility in exactly the same way.
Salvation is all of grace and damnation all of sin; God gets all the glory for salvation and none of the blame for damnation.
Salvation is mostly human achievement and damnation mostly divine judgment without human guilt.
Salvation is by works; damnation is by lack of information.

questions.explanation: Spurgeon is quoted approvingly: 'He preaches salvation all of grace, and damnation all of sin... He gives God all the glory for every soul that is saved, but he won't have it that God is to blame for any man that is damned.'

questions.question: True or False: The four features of the divine call in the notes are that it must be essential, genuine, congruent, and successful.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The conclusion lists the call as: Essential (God must take the initiative), Genuine (offered to all), Congruent (humans are accountable), and Successful (God’s purposes are accomplished).

quizzes.title: Conversion – Definition and Timing
quizzes.description: Definition of conversion and its relation to regeneration from Part 3c.

questions.question: According to the notes, what is the definition of conversion?

options.text: “Conversion is our willing response to the Gospel call, in which we sincerely repent of sin and place our trust in Christ for salvation.” (Grudem, 709)
Conversion is the act of God whereby the Holy Spirit imparts eternal life to the believer.
Faith is the “laying hold of the promises and work of Christ.” (Erickson, 951)
Repentance is the full apprehension of one’s miserable, lost estate, which leads to a renunciation of sin.

questions.explanation: The notes define conversion as: “Conversion is our willing response to the Gospel call, in which we sincerely repent of sin and place our trust in Christ for salvation.” (Grudem, 709)

questions.question: What two parts make up conversion in the notes?

options.text: Conversion is made up of two distinguishable yet inseparable parts: repentance and faith.
Conversion is made up of two distinguishable yet inseparable parts: calling and regeneration.
Conversion is made up of two distinguishable yet inseparable parts: justification and adoption.
Conversion is made up of two distinguishable yet inseparable parts: knowledge and works.

questions.explanation: Immediately after the definition, the notes state: “Conversion is made up of two distinguishable yet inseparable parts: repentance and faith.”

questions.question: How does the lecture describe the relationship between true repentance and true faith?

options.text: True repentance and true faith are like the two sides of a coin—it is impossible to have one without the other.
True repentance and true faith are unrelated experiences that may or may not occur together.
True repentance and true faith are both optional additions to regeneration.
True repentance and true faith are identical and cannot be distinguished in any way.

questions.explanation: The notes say: “True repentance and true faith are like the two sides of a coin—it is impossible to have one without the other.”

questions.question: What does the notes say about the timing of conversion and regeneration?

options.text: Conversion, as an event, occurs coincidentally with regeneration.
Conversion, as an event, occurs many years after regeneration.
Conversion, as an event, occurs before the Gospel call.
Conversion, as an event, occurs instead of regeneration.

questions.explanation: Under 'Timing' the notes say: “Conversion, as an event, occurs coincidentally with regeneration.”

questions.question: How do the notes summarize your professor’s view of how sinners are enabled to believe?

options.text: “your professor holds that the convicting work of the Holy Spirit and the effectual call that accompanies the preaching of the Gospel enables a sinner to believe.”
your professor holds that baptism washes away the curse of Original Sin, frees the will, and regenerates the recipient.
your professor holds that we do not believe in order to be born again; we are born again that we may believe.
your professor holds that faith is the consent of the will to the assent of the understanding.

questions.explanation: The notes explicitly state: “With the latter, your professor holds that the convicting work of the Holy Spirit and the effectual call that accompanies the preaching of the Gospel enables a sinner to believe.”

questions.question: What does the notes say happens to those who are converted?

options.text: Those who are converted are born again.
Those who are converted become part of the covenant but are not yet born again.
Those who are converted will later be regenerated through baptism.
Those who are converted are no longer in need of the Holy Spirit.

questions.explanation: In the same sentence the notes add: “Those who are converted are born again.”

questions.question: How does the notes describe this order (conversion then regeneration) in relation to Scripture?

options.text: This order is a later theological development and is not found in Scripture.
This order seems to be the testimony of Scripture.
This order is contradicted by all the cited passages.
This order was rejected by the Reformers and Puritans.

questions.explanation: The notes conclude the paragraph: “This order seems to be the testimony of Scripture. (Acts 2:38; 16:31; Rom. 10:13; John 3:16, 18, 36)”

questions.question: True or False: The notes describe conversion as “our willing response to the Gospel call.”

options.text: “Conversion is our willing response to the Gospel call, in which we sincerely repent of sin and place our trust in Christ for salvation.” (Grudem, 709)
Conversion is the act of God whereby the Holy Spirit imparts eternal life to the believer.

questions.explanation: The definition given is: “Conversion is our willing response to the Gospel call, in which we sincerely repent of sin and place our trust in Christ for salvation.” (Grudem, 709)

questions.question: True or False: The notes say that many Covenant theologians understand regeneration as being chronologically prior to conversion.

options.text: “Many Covenant theologians understand regeneration as being chronologically prior to conversion (often they connect regeneration with infant baptism).”
Many Covenant theologians understand conversion as being chronologically prior to regeneration.

questions.explanation: The notes explicitly state: “Many Covenant theologians understand regeneration as being chronologically prior to conversion (often they connect regeneration with infant baptism).”

questions.question: According to the notes, how do Grudem and Strong differ from Erickson and Demarest on the logical priority between regeneration and conversion?

options.text: (Grudem and Strong: regeneration is   prior.  Erickson and Demarest: conversion is prior).
(Grudem and Strong: conversion is prior.  Erickson and Demarest: regeneration is   prior).
They all agree that regeneration and conversion are identical and cannot be ordered.
They all agree that neither regeneration nor conversion is necessary for salvation.

questions.explanation: The notes say: “Among those who agree that these two aspects of salvation are simultaneous, there is debate as to which is logically prior.  (Grudem and Strong: regeneration is   prior.  Erickson and Demarest: conversion is prior).”

quizzes.title: Conversion – Repentance
quizzes.description: Definitions, biblical terms, components, and characteristics of repentance from Part 3c.

questions.question: What definition of repentance is given in the notes?

options.text: “Repentance is the full apprehension of one’s miserable, lost estate, which leads to a renunciation of sin.”
Repentance is the act of God whereby the Holy Spirit imparts eternal life to the believer.
Faith is the “laying hold of the promises and work of Christ.” (Erickson, 951)
Conversion is our willing response to the Gospel call, in which we sincerely repent of sin and place our trust in Christ for salvation.

questions.explanation: Under 'Repentance' the notes state: “Definition: Repentance is the full apprehension of one’s miserable, lost estate, which leads to a renunciation of sin.”

questions.question: What quotation from H.A. Ironside is included in the repentance definition section?

options.text: “Repentance is a recognition of the need of grace, not an act of merit opposed to grace.”
“Faith is the consent of the will to the assent of the understanding.”
“The best image I have heard for faith is that of empty hands, open to receive that what Christ offers.”
“We do not believe in order to be born again; we are born again that we may believe.”

questions.explanation: Immediately after the definition the notes add: “'Repentance is a recognition of the need of grace, not an act of merit opposed to grace.'—H.A. Ironside”

questions.question: How does the notes define the Old Testament term 'nicham'?

options.text: “A change of the heart or disposition, a change of mind, a change of purpose, or an emphasis upon the change of one’s conduct.”
“to turn.”
“to change one’s way of life as the result of a complete change of thought and attitude with regard to sin and righteousness.”
“to regret afterwards.”

questions.explanation: Under 'Biblical Terms – Old Testament' the notes say: “nicham— 'to repent.'  'A change of the heart or disposition, a change of mind, a change of purpose, or an emphasis upon the change of one’s conduct.'”

questions.question: What description is given for the New Testament verb 'Metanoeo'?

options.text: “to change one’s way of life as the result of a complete change of thought and attitude with regard to sin and righteousness.” Not merely cognitive
“to change directions, to turn to God.”
“to regret afterwards.”
“to believe, trust in, to regard as true”

questions.explanation: The notes state: “Metanoeo—'to change one’s way of life as the result of a complete change of thought and attitude with regard to sin and righteousness.' Not merely cognitive”

questions.question: Which New Testament verb is defined as 'to change directions, to turn to God'?

options.text: Epistrepho
Metamelomai
Metanoeo
Batach

questions.explanation: Under 'New Testament' the notes list: “Epistrepho—'to change directions, to turn to God.'”

questions.question: How does the notes describe 'Metamelomai'?

options.text: “to regret afterwards.”  Speaks of an emotional state that does not necessarily lead to repentance.  Used of Judas in Matt. 27:3.
“to change one’s way of life as the result of a complete change of thought and attitude.”
“to lean upon, confide in.”
“to repent.”  “A change of the heart or disposition…”

questions.explanation: The notes say: “Metamelomai— 'to regret afterwards.'  Speaks of an emotional state that does not necessarily lead to repentance.  Used of Judas in Matt. 27:3.”

questions.question: What do the notes say about sorrow by itself in repentance?

options.text: “In itself, sorrow has no healing power.”
Sorrow is sufficient to bring about complete repentance.
Sorrow always leads to repentance and salvation.
Sorrow is identical with repentance in every case.

questions.explanation: In the section on the emotions the notes state: “In itself, sorrow has no healing power.”

quizzes.title: Union with Christ — Quiz 1

False

Spiritual disciplines
Jesus Christ
The ordinances of the church

questions.explanation: “The Locus of Salvation: Jesus Christ. God accomplished and is accomplishing this work through his Son, Jesus Christ.”

questions.question: True or False: Union with Christ is presented as the whole of salvation in which other aspects are subsets.

options.text: True
False

John
Paul
James

‘To those who are sanctified in Christ Jesus’ (1 Cor 1:2)

options.text: John Calvin
Wayne Grudem
John Murray
Millard Erickson

questions.explanation: “Union with Christ is a phrase used to summarize several different relationships between believers and Christ… we are in Christ, Christ is in us, we are like Christ, and we are with Christ.”

quizzes.title: Salvation: Justification (Components of Salvation I)
quizzes.description: Examines competing views of justification and the Reformed/Evangelical understanding.

questions.question: According to the Reformed and Evangelical definition, what happens in justification?

options.text: God declares the sinner righteous by crediting the righteousness of Christ to the believer.
God makes the sinner inwardly righteous by the infusion of Christ’s righteousness.
God regards a person as righteous when he follows Christ’s moral example closely enough.
God counts the believer’s faith itself as the full basis and substance of righteousness.

questions.explanation: Declared Righteous—Reformed and Evangelical: Definition: The righteousness of Christ is credited to us when we are united to him by faith. Justification is the legal act of God by which He declares the sinner righteous on the basis of his relationship to Jesus Christ and His finished work.

questions.question: True or False: Pelagianism teaches that man is born spiritually neutral and, with the assistance of grace, can obey the demands for righteousness and holiness presented in Scripture.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Pelagius argued that man is born spiritually neutral and with the assistance of grace he can obey the demands for righteousness and holiness presented in the Scripture.

questions.question: In Roman Catholic teaching about justification, what is identified as the first justifying event?

options.text: Adult profession of faith at confirmation
Infant baptism
Confession followed by penance
Receiving the Eucharist for the first time

questions.explanation: Faith is essential to salvation, but one is not saved by faith alone. Justification starts with works rather than faith because the first justifying event is infant baptism.

questions.question: Which view interprets justification in the light of the governmental theory of the atonement?

options.text: Reformed and Evangelical
Wesleyan Arminianism
Roman Catholicism
Pelagianism

questions.explanation: Wesleyan Arminianism interprets justification in the light of the governmental theory of the atonement.

questions.question: True or False: In the Roman Catholic understanding, justification and sanctification are essentially the same reality, so that God views as righteous the one who becomes righteous.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Roman Catholicism sees justification and sanctification as synonyms: God views as righteous the one who becomes righteous.

questions.question: According to the Council of Trent (session six, canon nine), what is pronounced on anyone who says that the sinner is justified by faith alone with no other cooperation required?

options.text: He is declared blessed.
He is considered merely immature.
Let him be anathema.
He must perform additional penance.

questions.explanation: “If anyone says that the sinner is justified by faith alone, meaning thereby that no other cooperation is required for him to obtain the grace of justification… let him be anathema.” (Council of Trent, session six, canon nine).

questions.question: True or False: In the Reformed and Evangelical view, justification is a transformative process that primarily describes the inner moral change taking place within the believer.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Justification is a forensic, or legal, declaration. It is declarative, not transformative; it deals with how God sees us in Christ, not with the transformation Christ is doing within us.

questions.question: In the biblical argument from Romans 3–4, how do Abraham and David together illustrate justification by grace?

options.text: Abraham shows that the best man must still be saved by grace, and David shows that grace can save even the one who has committed the worst of sins.
Abraham is justified by works, while David is justified by faith alone.
Abraham and David both demonstrate that justification is earned by law-keeping.
Abraham represents Old Testament justification, David represents New Testament sanctification.

questions.explanation: Paul uses two Old Testament examples: Abraham and David (Rom 4:1–9). Abraham demonstrates that the best man still must be saved by grace (4:3). David shows that grace can save even the one who has committed the worst of sins (4:5–8).

questions.question: In the Reformed and Evangelical understanding, what is the condition (or instrument) of justification?

options.text: Personal works of righteousness
Faith
Perseverance in holiness to the end of life
Participation in the sacraments

questions.explanation: The condition of justification is faith: “But to him who does not work but believes on Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is accounted for righteousness.” Faith is not the ground of justification, but it is the instrument by which we receive God’s justifying grace.

questions.question: When justification is described as involving the "crediting, or imputing, to our account the righteousness of Christ," which picture best captures Paul’s teaching in Romans 4?

options.text: Our sins are ignored while our efforts slowly accumulate merit before God.
The debt of our sins is imputed to Christ, while His righteousness is credited to us.
Our faith and Christ’s righteousness are combined into a single shared account.
Our works are debited to Christ so that His example can inspire further obedience.

questions.explanation: Justification is the crediting, or imputing, to our account the righteousness of Christ. In Romans 4:4–5, Paul uses a bookkeeping metaphor to describe how the debt of our sins was imputed to Christ while his righteousness was credited to us.

quizzes.title: Salvation: Sanctification (Components of Salvation II)
quizzes.description: Covers the nature of sanctification, perfectionist views, and the progressive view.

questions.question: What is the basic meaning of the primary biblical terms translated "to sanctify"?

options.text: To inspire and to illumine
To separate or to set apart as holy
To forgive and to forget
To justify and to acquit

questions.explanation: Biblical terms: Whether Hebrew or Greek, the terms for “sanctify,” “saint,” and “holy” derive from the same word group. The words translated “to sanctify” basically mean “to separate.” In the Old Testament, qadesh means “to be consecrated,” “be holy,” and in the New Testament hagiazo basically means “to separate,” or “to set apart.”

questions.question: True or False: In the progressive view, sanctification is presented as having both a positional (objective) aspect and an experiential (ongoing) aspect.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The progressive view holds that the Bible presents sanctification in a twofold way: sanctification is an objective, positional reality and a subjective, ongoing experience. At conversion, God positionally sets the believer apart as holy, and the Christian experiences the liberating power of his sanctification when by faith he lives by this truth.

questions.question: According to the definition given, what are the two main parts of sanctification?

options.text: Illumination and inspiration
Positional claiming and experiential purifying of the believer
Justification and glorification
Election and perseverance

questions.explanation: Sanctification is God’s claiming and subsequent purifying of the believer as his possession. Positional: God first claims the believer by setting him apart for himself. Experiential: God then cleanses the believer from sin by a persistent and progressive work of the Holy Spirit.

questions.question: True or False: In the sinless perfection view of sanctification, the believer is said to be perfected by an instantaneous second work of grace often described as a “second blessing.”

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The sinless perfection view (Wesleyan/Holiness tradition) teaches that by an instantaneous second work of grace (the “second blessing”), the believer is perfected.

questions.question: Which tradition teaches that, by an instantaneous second work of grace, the believer is perfected in what is often called the "second blessing"?

options.text: Reformed Baptist tradition
Wesleyan/Holiness tradition
Roman Catholic tradition
Molinist tradition

questions.explanation: The sinless perfection view, associated with the Wesleyan/Holiness tradition, holds that by an instantaneous second work of grace (the “second blessing”), the believer is perfected.

questions.question: In the Assemblies of God understanding of Spirit baptism, which sign is emphasized as the evidence of this experience?

options.text: A permanent end to temptation
Speaking in tongues
The ability to work miracles at will
Sinless perfection without further struggle

questions.explanation: Assemblies of God teaching denies that the second work destroys inbred sin. However, the baptism of the Spirit empowers the believer to holiness otherwise not possible, and this baptism is evidenced by speaking in tongues.

questions.question: True or False: According to the progressive view of sanctification, the struggle with sin is eliminated so that the Christian life is no longer described in terms of effort, struggle, warfare, suffering, or divine chastening.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Our spiritual advancement comes about in a context of “effort (1 Cor 9:24; 1 Tim 4:10; Heb 12:1), struggle (Rom 7:15–23; Gal 5:17), warfare (Eph 6:10–18; 1 Tim 6:12), suffering (Rom 5:3; Heb 10:32–34), and divine chastening (Ps 119:71; Heb 12:5–11).”

questions.question: What does Calvin’s statement, quoted in the section on sanctification, affirm about the relationship between justification and sanctification?

options.text: Christ justifies some whom he does not sanctify, and sanctifies others whom he does not justify.
Justification and sanctification are unrelated blessings that can be separated in the believer’s experience.
Christ justifies no one whom he does not at the same time sanctify; these benefits are joined by an indissoluble bond.
Sanctification is optional for believers who already possess justification.

questions.explanation: Sanctification is the inseparable twin of justification: “Christ justifies no one whom he does not at the same time sanctify. These benefits are joined together by an everlasting and indissoluble bond.” (John Calvin, Inst. 3.16.1).

questions.question: Which pair of concepts summarizes the doctrine that believers are both kept by God and yet continue in faith and obedience?

options.text: Election and foreknowledge
Preservation and perseverance of the saints
Justification and glorification
Illumination and inspiration

questions.explanation: The Bible teaches both the preservation and the perseverance of the saints: Preservation (eternal security, “once saved, always saved”) and perseverance (the work of regeneration and sanctification eventually and inevitably manifests itself in the life of every believer).

questions.question: Which illustration is used to picture the up-and-down yet overall upward progress of the Christian’s sanctification?

options.text: A river that never changes its course
A ball bouncing down a stairway, except the Christian’s pilgrimage moves in the opposite (upward) direction
A straight line that never bends or dips
A mountain that collapses into the sea

questions.explanation: The Christian life is one of battle and growth. The illustration is of a ball bouncing down a stairway: though it goes up and down, its general direction is down. The Christian’s pilgrimage is similar, but in the opposite direction: our progress may go up and down, but the overall direction is up.

quizzes.title: Resurrection: Biblical Testimony and Worldview Contrast
