quizzes.description: Covers key Old and New Testament texts and how bodily resurrection contrasts with Greek and pagan views.

questions.question: What does the opening summary of the resurrection doctrine affirm about the future?

options.text: That only the righteous will experience a spiritual resurrection at death.
That both the just and the unjust will be raised in a future resurrection, with this truth stressed especially in the New Testament.
That the soul alone survives death while the body is left behind forever.
That resurrection is mainly a metaphor for moral renewal in this life.

questions.explanation: The section begins: "The Resurrection: The Bible repeatedly affirms a future resurrection of the both the just and the unjust, with more emphasis given to it in the New Testament than in the Old Testament."

questions.question: Among the Old Testament passages cited, which one is said to be universally acknowledged as clearly teaching that the dead will one day rise?

options.text: Isaiah 26:19
Daniel 12:2
Psalm 23:6

questions.explanation: In the Old Testament section we read: "Three texts are generally given at pointing to a future resurrection. However, only the Daniel passage is universally acknowledged as unambiguously teaching that the dead shall one day rise." The passage cited is Daniel 12:2.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Maccabees 7 is highlighted as one of the clearest Apocryphal references to bodily resurrection, where martyred brothers comfort one another with the promise that the King of the universe will raise them up.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Under "Intertestamental writings (the Apocrypha)" we are told: "The clearest references to bodily resurrection in the Apocrypha appear in 2 Maccabees 7. As seven brothers and their mother are martyred by Antichus Epiphanes, they comfort one another with the promise of the resurrection," including the line, "The King of the universe will raise us up to an everlasting renewal of life" (2 Macc 7:9).

questions.question: How did Greek philosophical thought typically view the relationship between soul and body, in contrast to Christian teaching on bodily resurrection?

options.text: The body was seen as a good gift to be resurrected, while the soul was considered temporary.
The body and soul were regarded as equal partners, both destined for eternal life together.
Death was viewed as the release of the immortal soul from the inferior prison-house of the body.
The soul was believed to perish with the body, making all talk of resurrection meaningless.

questions.explanation: The New Testament section states: "Faith in the resurrection of the body clearly distinguished Judeo-Christian beliefs from the Hellenistic and pagans views of that day." It cites Plato’s Phaedo: "Death was regarded as the release of the immortal soul from the prison-house or tomb (sema) of the body (soma), the latter being reckoned as inferior."

questions.question: Which critic mocked Christians as "philosomatic" or "body-loving" because of their belief in bodily resurrection?

options.text: Plato
Celsus
Plotinus
Origen

questions.explanation: The lecture notes: "Celsus (2nd cent AD) ridiculed the Christian notion of a resurrection by describing them as philosomatic—‘body-loving’ (Origen: Contra Celsum, 8.61). Plotinus (204-270 AD) declared that he was ashamed that he had a body."

questions.question: True or False: The doctrine of the resurrection was a central point of disagreement between the Pharisees and the Sadducees.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: After describing pagan mockery, the outline notes: "The doctrine of the resurrection was a major dividing point between the Pharisees and the Sadducees (Matt 22:23-33)."

questions.question: In Acts 17:32, how did some listeners in Athens respond when they heard Paul preach about the resurrection of the dead?

options.text: They immediately repented and believed.
They ignored it and asked Paul to talk more about idols.
Some mocked, while others said they would hear him again on this matter.
They arrested Paul for blasphemy against the gods of Athens.

questions.explanation: The notes cite: "‘And when they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some mocked, while others said, ‘We will hear you again on this matter.’’—Acts 17:32 NKJ," followed by the summary, "They said don’t call us. We will call you."

questions.question: True or False: For the apostles and the New Testament church, the resurrection of Christ confirmed beyond doubt the reality of a bodily resurrection for believers.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline states: "For the Apostles and the NT Church, the resurrection of Christ established beyond question the reality of a bodily resurrection."

questions.question: How does Romans 6:5 connect the believer’s future with Christ’s resurrection?

options.text: It says that believers are already resurrected in every sense and will never experience physical death.
It teaches that only martyrs will share in the likeness of Christ’s resurrection.
It promises that those united with Christ in the likeness of His death will certainly be united with Him in the likeness of His resurrection.
It warns that union with Christ in death does not guarantee any future bodily hope.

questions.explanation: The passage quoted reads: "‘For if we have been united together in the likeness of His death, certainly we also shall be in the likeness of His resurrection,’—Rom 6:5 NKJ," grounding our future resurrection in our present union with Christ.

questions.question: According to the survey of Scripture, which Testament places greater emphasis on the doctrine of the resurrection?

options.text: The Old Testament alone
The New Testament
The Apocrypha
Neither; the subject is only in later church tradition

questions.explanation: The opening sentence of the section states that there is "a future resurrection of the both the just and the unjust, with more emphasis given to it in the New Testament than in the Old Testament."

quizzes.title: Resurrection: Timing and Competing Views
quizzes.description: Explores metaphorical, spiritual, immediate, and eventual views of the resurrection and the argument for a future bodily resurrection at the end of the age.

questions.question: Which basic question frames the discussion in the section titled "The Timing and Number of the Resurrection"?

options.text: Whether the resurrection is spiritual or physical.
Whether Old Testament saints will be resurrected before New Testament believers.
Whether the resurrection occurs at death or at the end of the age.
Whether only martyrs receive a resurrection body.

questions.explanation: The lecture heading reads: "The Timing and Number of the Resurrection" and poses the key question, "The Resurrection: at death or at the end of the age?"

questions.question: How does Harry Emerson Fosdick’s "Metaphorical View" reinterpret the resurrection?

options.text: He affirms a literal resurrection of the flesh while denying the immortality of the soul.
He treats resurrection simply as a metaphor for the immortality of the soul and rejects the idea of a bodily resurrection.
He argues that resurrection happens repeatedly throughout a believer’s sanctification.
He sees resurrection as referring only to Christ’s experience, not to believers.

questions.explanation: In the "Metaphorical View" we are told that Fosdick "reinterpret[s] the resurrection to refer merely to the immortality of the soul." He says, "I believe in the persistence of personality (Immortality of the soul) through death, but I do not believe in the resurrection of the flesh," and calls for abandoning the old "mental framework" while keeping the "abiding experience" of belief in life after death.

questions.question: True or False: The outline concludes that Fosdick actually affirms the traditional doctrine of the resurrection with only minor adjustments.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: After summarizing his position, the outline concludes: "In short, Fosdick does not redefine the resurrection so much as he denies it."

questions.question: What characterizes the "Spiritual" view of the resurrection associated with Origen?

options.text: A purely non-physical, non-literal resurrection based on texts like 1 Corinthians 15 that speak of a life-giving spirit.
A return of the same physical body with no change whatsoever.
A denial of any resurrection or continued existence after death.
A view that only martyrs experience resurrection in any sense.

questions.explanation: The "Spiritual" view is described as follows: "Some contend that the resurrection should be understood entirely in non-physical, non-literal terms. Origen is the first to argue for a spiritual, non-material resurrection… He based his view on Paul’s statements [in] 1 Cor 15 that Christ was resurrected a ‘life-giving spirit’… and that ‘flesh and blood cannot inherit the Kingdom of God.’"

questions.question: How does John Hick describe the state of the dead in his "resurrection replica" model?

options.text: They are absorbed into an impersonal divine essence beyond all spatial description.
They immediately return in glorified physical bodies to the present world.
They appear as replicas in a distinct "resurrection world" that occupies its own space, separate from our present world.
They exist only as memories in the minds of those still living.

questions.explanation: The notes summarize Hick’s view: upon death a person appears "as a resurrection replica in a different world altogether, a resurrection world inhabited only by resurrected persons. This world occupies its own space distinct from that with which we are now familiar."

questions.question: True or False: Frank Stagg’s "Immediate View" teaches that believers receive a new tangible body at death, a body that will be able eventually to interact with the physical world.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline states: "Immediate View: Some, such as Frank Stagg, contend that a person receives a new, tangible body upon death… Unlike Hick, Stagg argues that the resurrection body will be able to eventually interact with the physical world."

questions.question: Which biblical warning does the outline use to caution against an "immediate" resurrection view that proclaims the resurrection as already past?

options.text: 1 Corinthians 15:12–14, where Paul denies any resurrection at all.
2 Timothy 2:17–18, which condemns those who say the resurrection has already taken place and overthrow the faith of some.
Hebrews 6:4–6, which warns against falling away after enlightenment.
Revelation 20:4–6, which describes the first resurrection.

questions.explanation: The critique notes: "The immediate resurrection view seems to run the risk of Paul’s denunciation in 2 Tim 2," then quotes, "[They] have strayed concerning the truth, saying that the resurrection is already past; and they overthrow the faith of some" (2 Tim 2:17-18 NKJ).

questions.question: True or False: One argument against receiving a full resurrection body immediately at death is that there is no indication Jesus had a temporary heavenly body during the three days of His death.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: In arguing against an immediate resurrection, the notes state: "There is no indication that Jesus had a temporary heavenly body during the three days of His death."

questions.question: What theological problem is said to arise if believers receive a permanent heavenly body at death rather than at the final resurrection?

options.text: It would undermine the doctrine of justification by faith.
It would remove the need for an intermediate state.
It would break the continuity between this present body and the resurrected body.
It would contradict the existence of angels.

questions.explanation: The critique explains: "If we receive a heavenly body upon death, then the continuity between this body and the resurrected body is lost."

questions.question: In the argument for an eventual, physical resurrection, which phrase from John 6 is repeatedly used to describe the timing of the resurrection?

options.text: "In the twinkling of an eye"
"In the middle of the week"
"At the last day"
"At the hour of temptation"

questions.explanation: The notes argue that "Scripture repeatedly speaks of the dead being resurrected at the end of the age (‘at the last day’)," quoting John 6:39–40 and noting that Jesus promises, "I will raise him up at the last day" (also John 6:44, 54).

quizzes.title: Resurrection: One General Resurrection or Many?
quizzes.description: Examines arguments for a single general resurrection versus several staggered resurrections and outlines a dispensational scheme of resurrection events.

questions.question: True or False: The outline states that a general resurrection is the logical corollary of a- and post-millennialism, so that accepting those systems entails accepting a general resurrection.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Under "The argument for one general resurrection" we read: "A general resurrection is the logical corollary of a- and post-millennialism. Acceptance of the a- or post- system entails acceptance of a general resurrection."

questions.question: Which of the following passages is used to support the idea that the just and the unjust are raised in the same "hour," and thus is cited in favor of a general resurrection?

options.text: Daniel 12:2
Acts 24:15
All of the above are cited in this connection.

questions.explanation: The section lists several texts that speak of the resurrection of the just and the unjust together: Daniel 12:2, John 5:28–29, and Acts 24:15. It notes that proponents "observe that the text seems to indicate that the saved and unsaved are resurrection at the same ‘hour’" and that Paul speaks of "a resurrection" in Acts 24:15.

questions.question: In Acts 24:15, what wording does Paul use that is taken as support for a general resurrection?

options.text: "There will be many resurrections of the dead, at various times."
"There will be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and the unjust."
"There will first be the resurrection of the just, then much later the resurrection of the unjust."
"Only the righteous shall rise again."

questions.explanation: Acts 24:15 is quoted: "‘I have hope in God, which they themselves also accept, that there will be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and the unjust.’—Acts 24:15 NKJ." The notes emphasize that Paul speaks of "a resurrection"—singular.

questions.question: True or False: Premillennialists use Revelation 20 to argue that the thousand-year reign of Christ separates the resurrection of the saved from that of the damned, supporting the idea of multiple, staggered resurrections.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes state: "Premillennialists contend that the thousand year reign of Christ will separate the resurrection of the saved and that of the damned. Rev 20 explicitly speaks of two resurrections, and belief in distinct resurrections is the logical corollary to adherence to an earthly 1000 year reign."

questions.question: Which statement best summarizes how Hebrews 11:35 is used in the argument for multiple resurrections?

options.text: It speaks of believers hoping for a "better resurrection," suggesting that not all resurrections are identical.
It denies that any resurrection will occur after the Old Testament period.
It teaches that resurrection is only spiritual, not bodily.
It proves that the wicked will not be raised at all.

questions.explanation: In the section on several resurrections, Hebrews 11:35 is quoted—"Others were tortured, not accepting deliverance, that they might obtain a better resurrection"—as one of several texts that make distinctions between resurrections of the just and the unjust or speak of a "better" resurrection.

questions.question: How does the phrase "from the dead" (ek nekron) contribute to the case for distinct resurrections, according to Pentecost?

options.text: It shows that all people are raised at once with no distinction.
It indicates that the redeemed are raised out from among the dead, implying that other dead are left.
It proves that the resurrection has already happened.
It is simply another way of saying "from the grave" with no theological significance.

questions.explanation: The notes observe that several passages speak of the redeemed being raised "from the dead" (ek nekron) and explain: "These words signify ‘from the dead’ or, out of the dead, implying that the other dead are left" (Pentecost, 396).

questions.question: True or False: The outline notes that some passages can speak of both resurrections in one place, just as some Old Testament prophecies speak of both advents of Christ together even though we now know they are separated in time.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes say that texts like Daniel 12:2 and John 5:28–29 "speak of both resurrections" and add: "Just as some passages speak of both advents of Christ at the same time (Isa 61:1-2; cf. Luke 4:18-19), so similarly do some speak of both resurrections."

questions.question: In the dispensational understanding of Revelation 20, what is the "first resurrection"?

options.text: The resurrection of all people—saved and lost—at once.
The resurrection of martyrs who live and reign with Christ for a thousand years, over whom the second death has no power.
A purely symbolic resurrection referring to national Israel.
The resurrection of the wicked at the end of the millennium.

questions.explanation: Revelation 20:4–6 is quoted: "And they lived and reigned with Christ for a thousand years… This is the first resurrection. Blessed and holy is he who has part in the first resurrection. Over such the second death has no power." Premillennialists see this as the resurrection of the saved prior to the millennium.

questions.question: According to the dispensational scheme outlined, which of the following is NOT one of the four distinct resurrection events within the broader "first" and "second" resurrections?

options.text: Christ as the first fruits, with some understanding Old Testament saints to be raised with Him.
The church at the rapture.
Tribulation saints along with Old Testament saints at the end of the Tribulation.
A special resurrection of millennial believers after the final judgment described in Revelation 20:11–15.

questions.explanation: The four distinct events listed are: (1) Christ as the first fruits, with OT saints being resurrected with Christ; (2) the church at the rapture; (3) Tribulation saints along with Old Testament saints; and (4) the unsaved dead at the end of the Millennium. A separate resurrection of millennial believers after the great white throne is not included.

questions.question: In the dispensational perspective, how is Christ’s own resurrection related to the larger series of resurrection events?

options.text: It is unrelated to the future resurrection of believers.
It is treated as the first stage of the "first resurrection," described as the "first fruits" that begin a staggered series of resurrection events.
It is considered part of the second resurrection with the unsaved dead.
It is only a symbol for spiritual renewal in the church.

questions.explanation: The outline explains: "Dispensationalists make further distinctions within the first resurrection. They argue that the first resurrection is a staggered event… The four distinct resurrection (staggered) events are: (1) Christ as the first fruits (1 Cor 15:23)…" so Christ’s resurrection inaugurates the broader series.

quizzes.title: Resurrection: Nature and Glory of the Resurrection Body
quizzes.description: Focuses on 1 Corinthians 15:35–58, analogies for the resurrection body, and its transformed characteristics.

questions.question: True or False: The section on "The Nature of the Resurrection" emphasizes that the resurrection of Christ in 1 Corinthians 15:35–58 guarantees the future resurrection of believers.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The heading states: "The Nature of the Resurrection: The Resurrection of Christ Guarantees Our Resurrection (1 Cor. 15:35-58)."

questions.question: In Paul’s analogy of seeds in 1 Corinthians 15, what main point about the resurrection body is illustrated?

options.text: That the resurrection body is entirely unrelated to the present body.
That nothing truly dies; all bodies simply continue in their current form.
That what is sown is not the body that shall be, but God gives it a body as He pleases, showing continuity and transformation.
That only plants, not human beings, experience resurrection.

questions.explanation: The notes quote Paul: "What you sow is not made alive unless it dies. And what you sow, you do not sow that body that shall be, but mere grain… But God gives it a body as He pleases, and to each seed its own body" (1 Cor 15:36–38). This illustrates both continuity and transformation between the present body and the resurrection body.

questions.question: What does Paul’s analogy of different kinds of flesh (1 Cor 15:39) contribute to his teaching on the resurrection body?

options.text: It shows that all created beings have exactly the same kind of body.
It suggests that animals will not be present in the new creation.
It illustrates that there are various kinds of bodies, preparing us to accept that the resurrection body differs from our present one.
It argues that only spiritual beings will be raised.

questions.explanation: The notes cite: "All flesh is not the same flesh, but there is one kind of flesh of men, another flesh of beasts, another of fish, and another of birds" (1 Cor 15:39 NKJ), and list this as one of the analogies showing different kinds of bodies.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 15:40–41, Paul uses the glory of heavenly bodies and stars as an analogy. What does this imagery emphasize about the resurrection body?

options.text: That resurrected believers will literally become stars.
That there are differing degrees of glory, suggesting the surpassing glory of the resurrection body.
That the resurrection body is identical to our present body but located in space.
That only the sun and moon will be renewed, not human bodies.

questions.explanation: Paul writes: "There are also celestial bodies and terrestrial bodies; but the glory of the celestial is one, and the glory of the terrestrial is another… for one star differs from another star in glory" (1 Cor 15:40–41 NKJ). The notes list this as the analogy of stars, illustrating differing glories.

questions.question: True or False: In applying these analogies, Paul says that the body is sown in corruption but raised in incorruption, sown in dishonor but raised in glory, sown in weakness but raised in power, and sown a natural body but raised a spiritual body.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The application section quotes 1 Corinthians 15:42–44: "The body is sown in corruption, it is raised in incorruption. It is sown in dishonor, it is raised in glory. It is sown in weakness, it is raised in power. It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body."

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the five qualities of our resurrected bodies listed from Garrett’s summary?

options.text: More than the resuscitation of corpses
A different plane of being and living
Bodily, not just a continued non-corporeal existence
Subject once again to decay and death just as before

questions.explanation: Summarizing Garrett, the notes list five qualities: "1 - More than the resuscitation of corpses; 2 - A different plane of being and living; 3 - Bodily, not just a continued non-corporeal existence; 4 - Full redemption of the body; 5 - A different kind of body." Being "subject once again to decay and death" is the very opposite of these qualities.

questions.question: True or False: The summary of Paul’s argument says that the resurrected body comes from the old body but is infinitely more glorious than the old body.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The "Summing up" statement reads: "Paul is saying that the resurrected body comes from the old body, but is different from the old body in the sense that it is infinitely more glorious than the old body."

questions.question: What is meant by saying that the new body is "like the stars above the earth" and "fit for heaven" in 1 Corinthians 15:47–50?

options.text: The new body will no longer bear the image of Adam but will bear the image of the heavenly Man and be suited for the kingdom of God.
The new body will literally be made of starlight.
The new body will be invisible and purely symbolic.
The new body means believers will cease to be human.

questions.explanation: The notes comment: "Like the stars above the earth, the new body is fit for heaven (vv. 47–50): Heaven and earth united," citing 1 Cor 15:47–50 where Paul says we have borne the image of the man of dust but "shall also bear the image of the heavenly Man" and that "flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God."

questions.question: In the "mystery of the resurrection body" (1 Cor 15:51–52), what truth does Paul reveal about those who are alive when Christ returns?

options.text: They will miss out on the transformation and must first experience death.
They will be changed in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet, without all of them passing through death.
They will be taken to heaven with their present, unchanged bodies.
They will remain on earth while only the dead are raised.

questions.explanation: The notes introduce this as "The Mystery of the Resurrection Body (vv. 51–53): This transformation will occur to the living as well as the dead," quoting: "We shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed… at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, and the dead will be raised incorruptible, and we shall be changed" (1 Cor 15:51–52 NKJ).

questions.question: According to the explanation of "the moment" of resurrection, what vivid picture is used to describe the experience of believers who are alive at Christ’s coming?

options.text: They will slowly grow into their resurrection bodies over many years.
They will "sprout without being planted," being transformed without passing through physical death.
They will first become disembodied spirits for a long intermediate period.
They will be partially transformed, with full change delayed until after the millennium.

questions.explanation: Commenting on "the moment" (v. 52), the outline says: "The moment (v. 52)—some are going to sprout without being planted. That generation will be transformed without deatch [death]."

quizzes.title: Judgment: Overview and Biblical Images
quizzes.description: Covers the basic theology of judgment, biblical images of God as Judge, and the incremental nature of judgment in history.

questions.question: How is the theology of judgment described in relation to Scripture and our present age?

options.text: It appears only in a few late New Testament passages and is mostly irrelevant today.
It is woven throughout the times and the Bible, even though today there is a loss of a sense of pending judgment.
It is found mainly in apocryphal writings and not in the canonical Scriptures.
It was a concern only for Old Testament Israel and has been fulfilled already.

questions.explanation: The section begins: The theology of Judgment is woven throughout the times/Bible. Today there is a lost of a pending judgment.

questions.question: What basic idea is conveyed by the Old Testament term "sopet" for God as Judge?

options.text: One who inspires worship through sacrifice.
One who arbitrates and administrates justice.
One who predicts the future through visions and dreams.
One who commands armies in holy war but does not decide legal cases.

questions.explanation: Under the Biblical images of God as Judge we read: Judge: OT sopet—one who arbitrates and administrates justice (Ex 18:2-24; Deut 1:16).

questions.question: True or False: In the biblical imagery of judgment, kings are portrayed as sovereign lords who often heard cases and rendered judgments.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline adds another image: King: Sovereign Creator and Lord. In the Bible, kings often heard cases and rendered judgments (2 Sam 12:1-6; Acts 26).

questions.question: What is the significance of the New Testament term "bema" (judgment seat)?

options.text: It was a quiet place for private prayer in the temple.
It was where Roman rulers rewarded heroic soldiers and triumphant athletes, and where the magistrate tried cases.
It was a platform used only for military announcements, not legal proceedings.
It was a special seat for the high priest in the Jerusalem temple.

questions.explanation: The judgment seat is explained: NT bema—where Roman rulers rewarded heroic soldiers and triumphant athletes. It was also where the magistrate tried cases.

questions.question: According to Romans 14:11 and 2 Corinthians 5:10, what universal reality about judgment is emphasized?

options.text: Only church leaders will stand before the judgment seat of Christ.
Believers will appear before the judgment seat, but unbelievers will not.
We will all stand before the judgment seat of God or Christ and give an account for what we have done.
Judgment is limited to temporal consequences in this present life.

questions.explanation: The texts cited say: For we will all stand before the judgment seat of God and For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, that each one may receive the things done in the body.

questions.question: True or False: In the section on judgment as an incremental process, unbelievers are said, in one sense, to be already found guilty.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline states: Unbelievers, in one sense, are already found guilty, and then cites John 3:18–19 about the one who does not believe being condemned already.

questions.question: How are believers contrasted with unbelievers in the same discussion of judgment as an incremental process?

options.text: Believers have not yet been judged at all in any sense.
Believers are already found not guilty because they were justified at Calvary in Christ.
Believers will face a stricter condemnation than unbelievers.
Believers are exempt from any evaluation of their works.

questions.explanation: Just after speaking of unbelievers, the outline says: Believers, by contrast, are already (enjoyed by faith) found not guilty because they were justified at Calvary, and then cites Colossians 2:13–14.

questions.question: What do passages like Galatians 6:7–8 and 1 Thessalonians 4:6 illustrate about God's judgment in this present age?

options.text: God never intervenes in history with any kind of judgment until the last day.
God often judges nations and individuals in this present age, so that people reap what they sow and experience the Lord as the avenger in these matters.
Judgment passages apply only to Israel and not to the church.
Such texts refer only to natural consequences, not to any work of God.

questions.explanation: The outline asserts: God often judges nations and individuals in this present age, then quotes Galatians 6:7–8 and 1 Thessalonians 4:6 about God not being mocked and the Lord being the avenger in these matters.

questions.question: True or False: The outline teaches that judgment in this age is complete and final, so that no further judgment remains.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: After mentioning temporal judgments, it says: However, judgment in this age is incomplete and according to a plan and wisdom of God and later adds that the judgments of this life are mere approximations. There is more to come.

questions.question: What concise statement summarizes the idea that sin's own consequences can be an expression of judgment?

options.text: Judgment is always separate from human actions.
Judgment is often contained within the evil deeds themselves.
Judgment is unrelated to either deeds or desires.
Judgment is reserved only for overt persecution of the church.

questions.explanation: Summarizing Romans 1, the outline states: Judgment is often contained within the evil deeds themselves, and then illustrates this with God giving people over in Romans 1:26–28.

quizzes.title: Judgment: Revelation of God and the Great Separation
quizzes.description: Focuses on judgment as a revelation of God's character, patience, righteousness, wrath and vengeance, and the great separation at the end.

questions.question: According to the section "Judgment as the Revelation of God," what will happen when you stand before God in that day?

options.text: You will be able to negotiate the terms of your judgment.
You and God will both be truly revealed for what you are.
Only your outward religious performance will be evaluated.
Judgment will be postponed until all your questions are answered.

questions.explanation: The section on Judgment as the Revelation of God begins: There will come a day that you will come face-to-face with God and in that moment you will both be truly revealed for what you are.

questions.question: How is God's patience described as it relates to judgment?

options.text: It is a sign that God will ultimately overlook sin and never judge.
It is a holy timeliness and proportionality in which God holds back judgment until it is the only proper recourse.
It is frustration at being unable to act against sin.
It is ignorance of the true extent of human evil.

questions.explanation: Under God's patience we read: There is a holy timeliness and proportionality to God's judgments. He is longsuffering, bearing until judgment is the only proper recourse (2 Pet 3:9).

questions.question: True or False: Romans 2:5 is used to show that stubborn and unrepentant hearts are storing up wrath for themselves in the day of wrath and revelation of the righteous judgment of God.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Romans 2:5 is quoted: Because of your stubbornness and unrepentant heart you are storing up wrath for yourself in the day of wrath and revelation of the righteous judgment of God.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 26:9 teach about the effect of God's judgments on the world?

options.text: They will cause people to despair and abandon all hope.
They will teach the inhabitants of the world righteousness.
They will only affect Israel and not the nations.
They will have no discernible impact on human behavior.

questions.explanation: In the subsection on God's righteousness it quotes Isaiah 26:9: For when Your judgments are in the earth, the inhabitants of the world will learn righteousness.

questions.question: True or False: When God sets things right in judgment, heaven and earth will rejoice in celebration of God's perfect judgment.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline states: When God sets things right, Heaven and earth will rejoice in celebration of God’s perfect judgment, and then cites Psalm 96:11–13.

questions.question: How is God's vengeance distinguished from human vengeance in the notes?

options.text: It is uncontrolled rage that mirrors human anger.
It is closely associated with His wrath and describes the purpose and direction of His wrath as He repays wickedness.
It is a temporary emotion that quickly fades and has no lasting effect.
It is limited to Old Testament contexts and not applied in the New Testament.

questions.explanation: The section on God's vengeance explains: Closely associated with God’s wrath is His vengeance, which describes the purpose and direction of His wrath—God judges to repay wickedness, and then cites 2 Thessalonians 1:6–7.

questions.question: According to passages like Mark 4:22 and Luke 12:2–3, what will happen to what is hidden or covered at the time of judgment?

options.text: Hidden things will remain secret forever.
Only especially serious sins will be exposed.
Nothing hidden will remain concealed; what has been kept secret will come to light and be proclaimed.
All secrets will be forgiven without exposure.

questions.explanation: The notes quote Mark 4:22 and Luke 12:2–3: There is nothing hidden which will not be revealed, nor has anything been kept secret but that it should come to light, and that what is spoken in inner rooms will be proclaimed on the housetops.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 2:16 is cited to show that God will judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ according to the gospel.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline quotes Romans 2:16: In the day when God will judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ, according to my gospel.

questions.question: What expression is used for the final unveiling that separates the saved and the lost at judgment?

options.text: The great experiment
The great separation
The great silence
The great restoration

questions.explanation: A subsection is titled The great separation: God’s judgment will unveil the great separation between the saved and the lost, with images of wheat and tares (Matt 13:24–30) and sheep and goats (Matt 25:31–46).

questions.question: True or False: In Matthew 25:32–33, Jesus pictures the judgment of the nations as a shepherd separating sheep from goats, placing the sheep on His right and the goats on His left.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes quote Matthew 25:32–33: All the nations will be gathered before Him, and He will separate them one from another, as a shepherd divides his sheep from the goats, and He will set the sheep on His right hand, but the goats on the left.

quizzes.title: Judgment: Number of Judgments and Judgment of the Saved
quizzes.description: Covers the shocking element of judgment, debates about one versus many judgments, and the nature of the judgment of believers.

questions.question: What is identified as one of the more disturbing or shocking elements of the judgment to come?

options.text: That no one will be surprised because everyone expects to be condemned.
That many will be surprised when they are barred from heaven despite their religious activity.
That only angels will be judged, not human beings.
That judgment will be purely symbolic with no real consequences.

questions.explanation: The outline states: The shocking element of Judgment: One of the more disturbing aspects of the judgment to come is that many will be surprised when they are barred from Heaven, and then cites Matthew 7:22–23 and Matthew 25:11–12.

questions.question: True or False: Postmillennialists and amillennialists argue that a general judgment follows a general resurrection.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: In The Number of Judgments we read: A General Judgment: Post- and Amillennialists argue that a general judgment follows a general resurrection.

questions.question: How do premillennialists, in contrast, typically understand the number and timing of judgments?

options.text: They agree that there is only one judgment for all creatures at the same moment.
They contend that, just as there are staggered resurrections, there will be staggered judgments so that believers are judged prior to when the lost face God.
They deny any final judgment and see judgment only in historical events.
They restrict judgment solely to Israel and not to the church or nations.

questions.explanation: The outline explains: Multiple Judgments: Premillennialists contend that, just as there will be staggered resurrections (Rev 20:4–6), so shall there be staggered judgments so that believers be judged at a time prior to when the lost face God.

questions.question: According to the summary of Ryrie's view, how many distinct judgments does he list?

options.text: Three judgments
Five judgments
Seven judgments
Ten judgments

questions.explanation: After noting that a better way is to affirm multiple judgments without knowing the number, the outline says: According to (dispensationalist) Ryrie, there are seven judgments (Ryrie: 512–15).

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the specific judgments listed in Ryrie's sevenfold scheme?

options.text: Judgment of the Church
Judgment of holy angels for rewards
Judgment of Jesus for His own sins
Judgment of the canon of Scripture

questions.explanation: Ryrie’s list includes: Judgment of the Church (1 Cor 3:10–15; 2 Cor 5:10), Judgment of Old Testament saints, Judgment of saints of the Tribulation period, Judgment of Jewish survivors, Judgment of Gentile survivors, Judgment of Satan and fallen angels, and Judgment of the unsaved dead.

questions.question: True or False: The outline links the Judgment of the Church with 1 Corinthians 3:10–15 and 2 Corinthians 5:10 and notes that this will be examined in greater detail in the next section.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Ryrie’s first judgment is described as: Judgment of the Church (1 Cor 3:10–15; 2 Cor 5:10). Though not specifically stated, this judgment will apparently take place after the translation of the church (Rev 4:4; 11:15–18; 19:8, 14). We will look at this in greater detail in the next section.

questions.question: When, according to the outline, does the judgment of the unsaved dead occur?

options.text: At the same time as the rapture of the church.
Immediately after each person dies, with no future judgment.
At the end of the millennial reign, as described in Revelation 20:11–15.
Before the Tribulation begins, to determine who may enter it.

questions.explanation: The seventh judgment is listed as: Judgment of the unsaved dead. Occurs at the end of the millennial reign (Rev 20:11–15).

questions.question: According to the section "The Nature of the Judgment" for believers, what is this judgment not designed to determine?

options.text: Their rewards and commendation.
Their stewardship and service.
Their salvation, since that judgment occurred at Calvary.
Their spiritual gifts and natural abilities.

questions.explanation: Under The Nature of the Judgment we read: Not to determine salvation, for that judgment occurred at Calvary, and then Colossians 2:13–14 is cited.

questions.question: True or False: The doctrine of a believer's present justification teaches that we were found guilty at Calvary, punished in Christ, and justified when the sentence was fulfilled.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline explains: The doctrine of a believer’s present justification teaches that believers have already been judged. At Calvary believers were judged in Christ. We were found guilty, the sentence was passed, and when the sentence was fulfilled we were found not guilty but justified.

questions.question: How are works related to saving faith in the description of the judgment of believers?

options.text: Works are irrelevant and have no connection to faith at all.
Works are the price we pay to earn justification.
Works are the manifestation of saving faith, showing a life dominated by the fruit of the Spirit.
Works replace faith once a person has believed.

questions.explanation: In this section it says: Works as the manifestation of saving faith and cites that true faith demonstrates itself by a life dominated by the fruit of the Spirit.

quizzes.title: Judgment: Purpose for Believers and Judgment of the Lost
quizzes.description: Explores the purposes and motivations of judgment for believers and outlines the judgment of the lost at the great white throne.

questions.question: What is the first stated purpose of the judgment upon believers?

options.text: To determine whether they will enter heaven.
To receive commendation from Christ.
To compare them with Old Testament prophets.
To decide whether they may keep their spiritual gifts.

questions.explanation: Under The Purpose of the Judgment upon Believers the first purpose is: To receive commendation from Christ. The Bible uses a number of images for such commendation, including servants returning home, business reports, and the crowning of athletes.

questions.question: True or False: The Bible uses images such as servants returning, accounts being settled, and the crowning of athletes to depict Christ's commendation of believers at judgment.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline notes that the Bible uses a number of images for commendation, including servants returning home, business reports, and the crowning of athletes.

questions.question: According to Matthew 25:21, what words of approval does the faithful servant hear at judgment?

options.text: You have done enough; now depart from Me.
Well done, good and faithful servant; enter into the joy of your lord.
You almost measured up; try harder next time.
You have been judged according to your own standards.

questions.explanation: Matthew 25:21 is quoted: His lord said to him, Well done, good and faithful servant; you have been faithful over a few things, I will make you ruler over many things. Enter into the joy of your lord.

questions.question: What second major purpose of the judgment upon believers is mentioned after commendation?

options.text: To decide membership in the local church.
To give an account of stewardship as an examination of faithfulness, obedience, and service.
To reveal previously unknown doctrinal errors.
To determine who will rule over the angels.

questions.explanation: The second purpose given is: To give an account of stewardship. This is not a judgment of condemnation, but it is an examination of faithfulness, obedience, and service.

questions.question: True or False: One explicit purpose of the believer's judgment is "to receive or lose rewards."

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: A third stated purpose is: To receive or lose rewards, and the notes then list various rewards for suffering, sacrificing, serving, faithfulness, and laboring for Christ.

questions.question: According to Matthew 10:40–42, which simple act of service does Jesus say will "by no means lose" its reward?

options.text: Writing a theological treatise.
Giving a cup of cold water in His name to one of His little ones.
Building a large religious monument.
Traveling to Jerusalem once a year.

questions.explanation: In the section on rewards for serving Christ, Matthew 10:40–42 is cited, where Jesus teaches that whoever gives one of these little ones only a cup of cold water in the name of a disciple shall by no means lose his reward.

questions.question: According to the summary of the judgment of believers, what will our reward ultimately display about Christ?

options.text: That we were ultimately self-made successes.
That Christ is the true source of our victory and that we are trophies of His grace.
That heaven is a merit-based system with no grace involved.
That human achievement is equal to Christ's work.

questions.explanation: The outline explains that the judgment will show that we were trophies of God's grace and concludes: We will happily demonstrate that Christ is the true source of our victory.

questions.question: Which of the following is specifically mentioned as a motivation that a proper understanding of judgment should produce in believers?

options.text: To avoid all talk of judgment in evangelism.
To do evangelism, persuaded by the reality that all must appear before Christ.
To focus only on personal prosperity and blessing.
To judge others more harshly in the present.

questions.explanation: Under The Motivation of Judgment for Believers the first listed motivation is: To do evangelism, and 2 Corinthians 5:10–11 is cited about all appearing before the judgment seat of Christ and knowing the terror of the Lord, we persuade men.

questions.question: In the section "The Judgment of the Lost," who is identified as the Judge at the great white throne?

options.text: Moses
The apostle Paul
Jesus Christ
The archangel Michael

questions.explanation: The section on the Judgment of the Lost states: The Judge: Jesus Christ. The Father has given to the Son the right to act as judge over all creation (Matt 25:31; John 5:26–27; Acts 17:31).

questions.question: True or False: At the great white throne, unbelievers are judged on the basis of their deeds, with books being opened that record what they have done.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Under The Basis of Judgment we read: The Basis of Judgment: their deeds, and Revelation 20:12–13 is quoted: And books were opened ... and the dead were judged from the things which were written in the books, according to their deeds.

quizzes.title: Eternal State – Hell and the Basic Alternative
quizzes.description: Covers the stark either/or of salvation or perdition and Donne’s description of hell as the loss of God.

questions.question: When the Eternal State material summarizes the final outcome of every person, which alternative does it explicitly present?

options.text: A range from deeper to shallower experiences of God’s love, with no sharp division
A temporary period of discipline followed by eventual restoration for all
Either salvation or perdition, with no third, middle condition beyond God’s final verdict
Entrance into heaven for believers and purgatory for all others

questions.explanation: The Eternal State introduction stresses the sharpness of the choice: it insists that the ultimate outcome is not a spectrum but a binary: “It is salvation or perdition.”

questions.question: In John Donne’s depiction cited in the Eternal State section, what makes hell uniquely terrible compared to all other torments?

options.text: The intensity of the physical flames that exceed any earthly pain
The humiliation of being exposed before other condemned sinners
The everlasting absence of God and the impossibility of ever returning to His presence
The memory of wasted opportunities and unfulfilled earthly dreams

questions.explanation: Donne’s language makes the core horror of hell relational, not merely physical: he calls it “the hell of hells, the torment of torments,” describing “the everlasting absence of God, and the everlasting impossibility of returning to his presence… to be secluded eternally, eternally, eternally from the sight of God.”

questions.question: True or False: In Donne’s description, the focus of hell’s torment is the intensity of the fire, while separation from God is treated as a lesser, secondary aspect.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Donne explicitly reverses that order: he calls “the hell of hells, the torment of torments” not the flames, but “the everlasting absence of God, and the everlasting impossibility of returning to his presence… to be secluded eternally… from the sight of God.”

questions.question: Which statement best captures how the Eternal State material contrasts a modern instinct for a "third way" with the biblical presentation of final destiny?

options.text: Modern thought and Scripture alike insist that all people will finally converge in the same place with God.
Modern thought wants a softer middle, but Scripture reduces the outcome to a twofold division: salvation or perdition.
Both modern thought and Scripture picture many gradations between total salvation and total loss.
Scripture offers three basic outcomes: heaven, purgatory, and annihilation.

questions.explanation: Summarizing the Eternal State introduction, the outline insists on the sharpness of the biblical alternative—“It is salvation or perdition”—over against the impulse to imagine a more comfortable middle position.

questions.question: In light of Donne’s description, which of the following comes closest to the theological definition of hell implied in the Eternal State section?

options.text: Hell is primarily the experience of maximal physical pain inflicted by created agents.
Hell is the everlasting absence of God’s favorable presence and the hopeless impossibility of returning to communion with Him.
Hell is a remedial school by which all eventually return to God cleansed and restored.
Hell is a temporary holding place before souls are absorbed back into the divine essence.

questions.explanation: Donne’s language is taken to summarize the essence of hell: he highlights “the everlasting absence of God, and the everlasting impossibility of returning to his presence… to be secluded eternally… from the sight of God,” underscoring an eternal loss of communion rather than merely temporary discipline.

questions.question: True or False: The Eternal State introduction suggests that our contemporary culture generally lives with a vivid sense of “pending judgment” that shapes its priorities.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The introductory comments lament the opposite: they observe that “today there is a loss of a sense of pending judgment,” which is precisely why the doctrine of the eternal state must be recovered and taught.

questions.question: The description of hell as "everlasting absence" and "impossibility of returning" is doing which of the following theologically in the Eternal State discussion?

options.text: Redefining hell to remove any notion of God’s judgment
Emphasizing hell as the consummation of a chosen distance from God that is then fixed eternally
Denying that there is any conscious experience in hell at all
Arguing that God’s presence in hell is just as blessed as in heaven

questions.explanation: By calling hell “the everlasting absence of God, and the everlasting impossibility of returning to his presence… to be secluded eternally… from the sight of God,” the outline frames hell as a finally fixed alienation from God’s favorable presence, not merely a brief corrective phase.

questions.question: In the Eternal State material, why does the sharp alternative of “salvation or perdition” intensify, rather than diminish, the urgency of gospel proclamation?

options.text: Because it implies that most people will probably end up saved regardless
Because it locates the decisive turning point in philosophical speculation, not in personal response to Christ
Because if the only outcomes are salvation or perdition, then calling people from one to the other is a matter of eternal consequence
Because it assures that hell is only a metaphor and cannot be truly experienced

questions.explanation: The insistence that “It is salvation or perdition” underscores that no neutral outcome lies beyond the gospel; that binary, combined with Donne’s picture of “everlasting absence of God,” gives missionary urgency to the call to repentance and faith.

questions.question: True or False: Taken together, the introduction and Donne’s citation present the worst thing about perdition as the loss of God Himself rather than merely the loss of created blessings.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The Donne quotation centers hell’s horror on God’s absence: “the hell of hells, the torment of torments, is the everlasting absence of God, and the everlasting impossibility of returning to his presence… to be secluded eternally… from the sight of God,” making the loss of God Himself the essence of perdition.

questions.question: Which of the following most accurately pulls together the Eternal State introduction’s teaching on the two destinies and Donne’s image of hell?

options.text: Hell is a temporary phase leading ultimately to the same communion with God enjoyed by the saved.
The final division is between greater and lesser experiences of God’s nearness, but everyone remains within His embrace.
The final division is binary—“salvation or perdition”—and perdition is portrayed as an eternal, hopeless exclusion from the blessed presence of God.
Perdition is chiefly the loss of earthly pleasures, while God’s presence is unaffected.

questions.explanation: The Eternal State material insists that “It is salvation or perdition,” and the Donne citation fills out what perdition means: “the hell of hells, the torment of torments, is the everlasting absence of God, and the everlasting impossibility of returning to his presence… to be secluded eternally… from the sight of God.”

quizzes.title: Eternal State – Universalism
quizzes.description: Definition, major forms, arguments, and the biblical/theological response to universalism.

questions.question: How is universalism defined in the Eternal State material?

options.text: The view that God sincerely offers salvation to all, though many will finally be lost.
The view that the unrighteous will eventually be annihilated rather than punished forever.
The view that every person will eventually experience salvation and that by the end of the age there will be a universal reconciliation to God.
The view that only those who receive a post-mortem opportunity to repent will be saved.

questions.explanation: Universalism is defined as “the view that every person will eventually experienc[e] salvation… [and] by the end of the age there will be a universal reconciliation to God.”

questions.question: True or False: According to the Eternal State outline, universalism has only one main form, since all universalists reject historic Christian doctrines in the same way.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The material distinguishes “two broad approaches to universalism”: a “Pluralistic or liberal” form that “jettisons many classic Christian doctrine[s]…” and a “Conservative or ‘evangelical’” form that “holds to an orthodox Christology and atonement.”

questions.question: Which description best contrasts pluralistic (liberal) universalism with conservative (evangelical) universalism in the Eternal State section?

options.text: Pluralistic universalism retains supernaturalism and penal substitution, while conservative universalism rejects them.
Pluralistic universalism jettisons many classic Christian doctrines such as “Supernaturalism, Penal Substitution,” while conservative universalism “holds to an orthodox Christology and atonement.”
Pluralistic universalism is limited to the early church, while conservative universalism is only a modern phenomenon.
Pluralistic universalism confines salvation to Christians, while conservative universalism extends it to all religions.

questions.explanation: Pluralistic or liberal universalism “jettisons many classic Christian doctrin[e]… (e.g. John Hick). Supernaturalism, Penal Substitution are all rejected.” By contrast, the conservative or ‘evangelical’ form “holds to an orthodox Christology and atonement (e.g. George MacDonald; Thomas Talbott).”

questions.question: Which early Christian thinker is explicitly associated with apocatastasis, the doctrine of a final restoration of all things, including an ultimate reconciliation of even the devil with God?

options.text: Augustine of Hippo
Origen of Alexandria
Clement of Rome
John Chrysostom

questions.explanation: Among early adherents, the outline notes: “Origen: ‘apocatastasis’—the doctrine of the final restoration of… all things, and the ultimate reconciliation of Satan with God.”

questions.question: In the survey of historical and modern advocates, which pairing correctly matches a movement with leaders associated with universalism?

options.text: Primitive Baptist Universalists – Hosea Ballou and John Murray
Unitarian-Universalists – Hosea Ballou and John Murray
The Great Awakening – Charles Chauncy and Jonathan Edwards
Neo-orthodoxy – Friedrich Schleiermacher and John Owen

questions.explanation: Under “Recent advocates” we read: “Unitarian-Universalists—founded by Hosea Ballou (‘the father of American universalism’) and John Murray,” while “Primitive Baptist Universalists” are described separately as a faction of “Primitive ‘Hardshell’ Baptists… (‘no-hellers’).”

questions.question: True or False: The Eternal State material presents Karl Barth’s well-known statement that we must think of every human as elected in Christ as a straightforward endorsement of dogmatic universalism.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes list “many neo-orthodox: Karl Barth, Emil Brunner” among recent advocates and cite Barth’s line, “On the basis of the eternal will of God we have to think of every human as one for whom Jesus Christ is elected… God is Father.” But the context is a survey of proponents, not an unqualified endorsement of Barth’s conclusions.

questions.question: Universalist arguments in the Eternal State section are grouped under four headings. Which of the following correctly lists one of those headings AND a representative text?

options.text: The universal effects of the Atonement – Romans 5:18–19
The inevitability of post-mortem opportunity – 1 Peter 3:18–20
The temporary nature of punishment – Mark 9:43–48
The annihilation of the wicked – Philippians 3:19

questions.explanation: The outline states: “Arguments: Universalist arguments can be grouped under four points: The universal effects of the Atonement,” and then quotes Romans 5:18–19: “as one trespass led to condemnation for all men, so one act of righteousness leads to justification and life for all men… by the one man’s obedience the many will be made righteous.”

questions.question: Which universalist appeal is grounded in texts like 1 Timothy 2:3–4, and how is it summarized in the Eternal State material?

options.text: The universal reign of God – God’s kingdom will eventually subdue every rival power.
The universal statements concerning salvation – all explicit ‘all’ texts must mean every individual will finally be saved.
The universal love of God – God “desires all people to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth,” and His will is thought always to be done.
The universal effects of judgment – God’s wrath will cleanse everyone in the same way.

questions.explanation: Under “The universal love of God” the notes quote 1 Timothy 2:3–4: “This is good, and it is pleasing in the sight of God our Savior, who desires all people to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth,” and then add, “God’s ‘will’ is always done,” as part of the universalist case.

questions.question: True or False: The response section concedes that if one affirms universal atonement, God’s universal love, and Christ’s universal reign, one must consistently embrace universalism.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The response explicitly denies this: “Affirming universal atonement, God’s universal love, and Christ’s [universal reign] does not entail embracing universalism. In fact, most Christians who affirm the above are not universalists.”

questions.question: How does the Eternal State material characterize the universalist appeal to emotion, especially in light of the Lewis and Packer quotations?

options.text: As a legitimate theological starting point that should override difficult biblical texts.
As a useful corrective to overemphasis on divine justice, making it the main argument for universalism.

As a deeply understandable human longing—Lewis says, “I would pay any price to be able to say truthfully: ‘All will be saved’”—but one that, as Packer puts it, makes universalism “a human wish seeking a divine warrant.”
As irrelevant to the discussion, since Scripture never addresses the emotions.

questions.explanation: The notes quote Lewis: “I would pay any price to be able to say truthfully: ‘All will be saved,’” then add Packer’s comment: “Surely Lewis speaks for us all… But the crucial word is truthfully,” and conclude, “The universalist appeal to emotion: Packer has it right. Universalism is a human wish seeking a divine warrant.”

quizzes.title: Eternal State – Post-Mortem Opportunity
quizzes.description: Definition, key advocates, 1 Peter 3:18–20, and the main interpretive options.

questions.question: According to the Eternal State section, what is the defining claim of the view called Post-mortem Opportunity?

options.text: That God will certainly save all people before they die, so that no one faces judgment after death.
That the opportunity for salvation, at least for certain ones, does not end at death and there can be an opportunity to be saved after death.
That only Old Testament saints receive a second chance at salvation after death, not anyone else.
That death itself is an illusion and therefore there is no need for post-mortem salvation.

questions.explanation: The view is defined this way: "Definition: The opportunity for salvation, at least for certain ones, does not end at death… Hell is exclusion from communion with God, but not from his presence. There is an opportunity to be saved after death."

questions.question: True or False: The main distinction between Post-mortem Opportunity and universalism, as stated in the Eternal State material, is that Post-mortem Opportunity insists that there is no guarantee that all will be saved.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: After defining the view, the outline adds: "The main distinction of this view from universalism is that there is no guarantee that all will be saved."

questions.question: Which grouping correctly identifies several theologians listed together as advocates of some form of Post-mortem Opportunity?

options.text: Pannenberg, Bloesch, Patterson, Pinnock, Erickson, Fackre
Augustine, Anselm, Calvin, Luther, Edwards
John Hick, Hosea Ballou, John Murray
Origen, Athanasius, Tertullian

questions.explanation: The section introduces the view with this list: "(Pannenberg, 1972; Bloesch, 1978; Patterson, 1982; Pinnock, 1992; Erickson, 1996; Fackre, 1996)."

questions.question: Which combination best represents the scriptural and confessional basis appealed to by proponents of Post-mortem Opportunity in the Eternal State notes?

options.text: Romans 9 and the Nicene Creed statement about the Son being begotten, not made.
1 Peter 3:18–20, 1 Peter 4:6, the phrase He descended into hell from the Apostles Creed, and also Acts 2:31 and Ephesians 4:9–10.
Genesis 6 and the Athanasian Creed’s clauses on the Trinity.
Revelation 21–22 and the phrase Light from Light in the Nicene Creed.

questions.explanation: The scriptural basis is laid out as: "Scriptural basis: 'For Christ also suffered once for sins… in which he went and proclaimed to the spirits in prison'—1 Peter 3:18–20 (ESV)… 'the gospel was preached even to those who are dead'—1 Peter 4:6 (ESV)," and it adds: "Other passages appealed to are Acts 2:31 and Eph 4:9–10." This follows the Apostles Creed line: "He descended into hell."

questions.question: In the list of seven interpretive options for 1 Peter 3:18–20, what does the Second chance view say Christ did between His death and resurrection?

options.text: He announced His triumph and the finality of condemnation to humans who had already rejected Him.
He proclaimed release to Old Testament saints who had previously believed.
He preached to humans in hell, offering them a second chance to receive the message they had rejected while on earth.
He preached through Noah in advance of the flood to warn that generation.

questions.explanation: The outline labels one option as: "Second chance: Between his death and resurrection, Christ preached to humans in hell, offering them a second chance to receive the message they had rejected while on earth."

questions.question: True or False: In the First chance interpretation of 1 Peter 3:18–20, the passage is taken to show that those who never heard the gospel in this life will have the opportunity after death.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes distinguish this view: "First chance: Illustrates that those who’ve never heard the gospel will have the opportunity after death (Fackre). This became known as the 'Andover solution' to questions Hawaiian converts asked about their ancestors."

questions.question: According to one of the seven options, what is meant by the Announcement of doom to angels interpretation of Christ’s proclamation to the spirits in prison?

options.text: Christ preached the gospel to all angels, offering them a universal second chance.
Christ preached only to good angels, rewarding them for their faithfulness.
Christ announced His triumph and the finality of condemnation specifically to fallen angels who had mated with humans in the days of Noah.
Christ explained the plan of salvation to unfallen angels so they could evangelize humans.

questions.explanation: The notes describe this view: "Announcement of doom to angels: Same as previous, except that the hearers are fallen angels who had mated with humans in the days of Noah."

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the Announcement of deliverance interpretation of Christ’s proclamation in 1 Peter 3:18–20?

options.text: Christ proclaimed release to Old Testament saints, or to those who had repented just as Noah’s flood was occurring.
Christ proclaimed release to all humans without exception, including those persisting in unbelief.
Christ proclaimed release to fallen angels but not to any humans.
Christ proclaimed that there would be no possibility of deliverance for any creature.

questions.explanation: Under this option the outline says: "Announcement of deliverance: Christ proclaimed release to the OT saints, or to those who had repented just as Noah’s flood was occurring."

questions.question: True or False: Luther’s comment on 1 Peter 3:18–20 is quoted to show that, in his judgment, this passage is unusually clear and should be the primary basis for doctrine about the state of the dead.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Luther’s remark is the opposite: "This is a strange text and certainly a more obscure passage than any other passage in the New Testament. I still do not know for sure what the apostle means."

questions.question: Given Luther’s assessment of 1 Peter 3:18–20 and the complexity of the seven options, what caution does the Eternal State material implicitly support about using this passage for Post-mortem Opportunity?

options.text: That because Luther found it clear, this passage should override all other teaching on judgment.
That since the text is obscure, we should be cautious about letting it overturn the clearer biblical teaching on the finality of judgment after death.
That only pre-Reformation interpreters are qualified to use the text at all.
That the passage proves universal salvation beyond any doubt.

questions.explanation: By quoting Luther’s confession, "This is a strange text and certainly a more obscure passage than any other passage in the New Testament. I still do not know for sure what the apostle means," the notes underscore that such an obscure passage should not be used to overturn the more straightforward texts about judgment after death.

quizzes.title: Eternal State – Annihilationism / Conditional Immortality
quizzes.description: Definition, adherents, main arguments, and biblical responses to annihilationism (conditionalism).

questions.question: How does the Eternal State section define annihilationism in relation to the fate of the unrighteous after death?

options.text: The unrighteous will suffer consciously forever with no possibility of cessation.
The unrighteous will be restored after a finite period of purifying punishment.
Upon death the unrighteous will cease to exist, either immediately or eventually, so that their existence is finally extinguished.
The unrighteous will continue in a shadowy intermediate state but never be judged.

questions.explanation: The definition reads: “Annihilationism contends that upon death the unrighteous will cease to exist, either immediately or eventually.  Many annihilationists prefer the term ‘conditionalist.’”

questions.question: True or False: In the historical survey, Arnobius is mentioned as an early annihilationist who taught that the wicked would suffer forever without any “total extinction of being.”

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline says, “The first annihilationist appears to have been Arnobius (died c. 330),” and quotes him warning that the wicked “shall be punished in torment… and in the *total extinction of being and existence*.”

questions.question: Which of the following lists best reflects some of the modern evangelical voices noted as sympathetic to annihilationism or conditional immortality?

options.text: Karl Barth, Emil Brunner, John Hick
John Stott, Philip Hughes, Clark Pinnock, E. Earle Ellis
Origen, Gregory of Nyssa, Clement of Alexandria
Hosea Ballou, John Murray, Charles Chauncy

questions.explanation: Under “In recent days” the notes say annihilationism “has found a new home among evangelicals,” naming among others “John Stott, Phillip Hughes, Clark Pinnock, E Earle Ellis.”

questions.question: Annihilationists appeal to the claim that humans are only conditionally immortal. Which theological contrast do they draw with this claim?

options.text: That angels alone possess immortality, while humans never can.
That Scripture teaches the soul is naturally immortal in itself, apart from God.
That the doctrine of the immortality of the soul comes from Hellenistic philosophy, whereas the Bible teaches that “God alone possesses immortality” and grants eternal life only to believers.
That universalism is required because all creatures share the same immortal nature as God.

questions.explanation: The arguments include: “Humans are only conditionally mortal.  The doctrine of the immortality of the soul comes from Hellenistic philosophy.  The Bible teaches that ‘God alone possesses immortality’ (1 Tim 6:16) and gives eternal life only to those who believe (1 Cor 15:51–55).”

questions.question: Edward Fudge’s argument about the adjective aiōnios (“eternal”) in phrases like “eternal punishment” can be summarized in which way, according to the Eternal State outline?

options.text: He insists that aiōnios refers only to quality (heavenly) and never to time.
He argues that aiōnios in judgment texts actually means “age-long,” a long but finite span that ends before the final restoration.
He contends that when the Bible speaks of “eternal punishment” and “eternal fire,” it is describing the eternality of the effects (final destruction), not an endless process of conscious torment.
He claims that aiōnios is a textual corruption and should be omitted from punishment passages.

questions.explanation: The notes summarize Fudge: “When the Bible speaks of the everlasting nature of Hell, this is best understood in terms of effects rather than duration… Christ obtained ‘eternal redemption’ (Heb 9:12)… the unsaved shall experience ‘eternal destruction’ (2 Thess 1:9).  Passages which speak of ‘eternal punishment’ (Matt 25:46) and ‘eternal fire’ (Matt 25:41) should be understood similarly.  Effects are eternal.”

questions.question: Annihilationists appeal to Isaiah 66:24 to support their reading of hell imagery. How do they interpret the scene of worms and fire there?

options.text: As evidence of endless conscious torment endured by the slain themselves.
As a picture of dead bodies of God’s enemies being consumed, which are “obviously not conscious.”
As proof that all people, including the wicked, will eventually be restored.
As symbolic of temporary disciplinary measures in this life only.

questions.explanation: Under OT imagery the notes say: “NT images of Hell should be understood in the light of the OT passage (Isa 66:24)… they shall go out and look on the dead bodies of the men who have rebelled against me… and they shall be an abhorrence to all flesh. The… dead bodies of God’s enemies… are obviously not conscious.”

questions.question: True or False: One moral objection raised by Clark Pinnock and cited in the Eternal State material is that “everlasting torment is intolerable” and would make God resemble the commandant of a concentration camp.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline quotes Pinnock: “As I intimated earlier, everlasting torment is intolerable from a moral point of view because it makes God into a… cruel and merciless God,” and refers to his charge that God is like “the commandant of a gulag.”

questions.question: In responding to the argument that the wicked are “destroyed,” how does the Eternal State section explain the meaning of the word apollymi?

options.text: It always means total non-existence and can never mean anything else.
It primarily describes moral improvement rather than any form of loss.
It means “to ruin” or bring to ruin, rather than necessarily “to cease to exist.”
It refers only to national judgment and never to individual destinies.

questions.explanation: The response begins: “To the argument that the wicked are ‘destroyed’: The word ‘destruction’ (apollymi) means ‘to ruin’ rather than ‘to cease to exist.’”

questions.question: Which passage is cited in the Eternal State response to show the ongoing nature of torment, specifically that “the smoke of their torment goes up forever and ever” and they have “no rest, day or night”?

options.text: Matthew 25:41–46
2 Thessalonians 1:9
Revelation 14:11
Isaiah 66:24

questions.explanation: In the response, after discussing destruction language, the notes appeal to Revelation: “ ‘And the smoke of their torment goes up forever and ever, and they have no rest, day or night’—Rev 14:11 (ESV).”

questions.question: True or False: In answer to the claim that everlasting punishment is morally intolerable, Morgan is quoted as saying that annihilationism dissolves the moral problem of evil rather than creating new ones.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The notes actually say the opposite: “This argument assumes that everlasting punishment serves no purpose… ‘Unlike annihilation, everlasting punishment does not dissolve all moral problems, it does not create them.’—Morgan: 2004, 208.”

quizzes.title: Eternal State – Eternal Punishment of the Lost
quizzes.description: Punishment, destruction, and banishment motifs for the eternal state of the lost.

questions.question: According to the “Predominant motifs” section, which three categories together summarize the New Testament’s main ways of portraying the fate of the lost?

options.text: Judgment, purgation, and universal restoration
Punishment, destruction, and banishment
Remorse, reform, and rehabilitation
Ignorance, illusion, and enlightenment

questions.explanation: The outline introduces this section with: “Predominant motifs: Can be grouped in three categories (Harmon: 1992, 217-24; Morgan: 2004, 142-51; Powys: 1998, 281-93) Punishment… Destruction… Banishment: Hell is a state of permanent exile.”

questions.question: True or False: The Eternal State material, citing Morgan, stresses that every New Testament author treats hell primarily as annihilation rather than as punishment.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Under the first motif the outline states: “Punishment: ‘That hell is punishment is communicated by every New Testament author.’—Morgan, 143.”  The emphasis is on punishment, not on annihilation.

questions.question: What two features of hell’s punishment are highlighted in the comments following Matthew 23:31–33 and Luke 16:25?

options.text: That it is deserved and consists of suffering
That it is accidental and mainly symbolic
That it is rehabilitative and temporary
That it is unknown and not described in Scripture

questions.explanation: The section reads: “The punishment is deserved and therefore just.  ‘Thus you witness against yourselves that you are sons of those ... are you to escape being sentenced to hell?’—Matt 23:31-33 (ESV)  The punishment consists of suffering.  ‘But Abraham said, 'Child, remember that you in your lifetime re... he is comforted here, and you are in anguish.’—Luke 16:25 (ESV).”
