questions.question: How does the Eternal State section show that the punishment of the lost is conscious, not merely an unconscious state of loss?

options.text: By arguing that the dead no longer feel anything at all
By appealing to Paul’s statement that “the dead know nothing”
By citing Jesus’ description: “In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.”
By appealing to the silence of the Old Testament about hell

questions.explanation: Under the punishment motif the notes state: “The punishment is conscious.  ‘In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth."—Matt 8:12 (ESV).”

questions.question: True or False: The Eternal State outline treats the phrase “they will be tormented day and night forever and ever” (Rev 20:10) as a key text for the eternal nature of punishment.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Immediately after stating “The punishment is eternal,” the outline quotes: “ ‘and they will be tormented day and night forever and ever.’—Rev 20:10 (ESV).”

questions.question: How is “destruction” explained under the second motif so that it does not necessarily imply ceasing to exist?

options.text: Destruction is taken to mean that the wicked are never actually harmed.
Destruction is treated as a poetic synonym for sleep with no moral dimension.
Destruction is said to mean the loss of the creation’s intended end, so that something can be “destroyed” without losing the essence of its nature or existence.
Destruction is equated with universal restoration after a brief period of discipline.

questions.explanation: In the Destruction motif the notes state: “In both OT and NT, ‘destruction’ almost never carr... lose ‘the essence of its nature or function.’ (Moo: 2004, 105).”  It then cites Phil 1:28 and 2 Thess 1:9 as examples of “destruction” language.

questions.question: What is emphasized about the destiny of those described in 2 Thessalonians 1:9, as quoted in the Eternal State section?

options.text: That they will be annihilated without any reference to God’s presence or glory
That they will be punished with everlasting destruction away from the presence of the Lord and from the glory of His power
That they will continue in a neutral, morally indifferent state
That they will be restored to God after a short period of darkness

questions.explanation: The text quoted is: “ ‘These shall be punished with everlasting destruction from the p... of the Lord and from the glory of His power.’—2 Thess 1:9 (NKJ).”

questions.question: True or False: Under the third motif, the Eternal State outline explicitly describes hell as “a state of permanent exile.”

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The third motif is introduced as: “Banishment: Hell is a state of permanent exile.”

questions.question: Which of the following combinations of images and texts does the Eternal State material use to depict hell as banishment and exclusion from Christ and His kingdom?

options.text: “Outer darkness” and the New Jerusalem (Rev 21:1–4)
“I never knew you; depart from Me” (Matt 7:22) and the guests locked out in Matthew 25:11–12
“Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth” (Matt 5:5)
“You are the salt of the earth” (Matt 5:13)

questions.explanation: The Banishment motif explains: “Banishment: Hell is a state of permanent exile.  ‘And then I will declare to them, ‘I never knew you; depart from Me, you who practice lawlessness!’—Matt 7:22 (NKJ)… ‘Afterward the other virgins came also, saying, ‘Lord, Lord, ope... ssuredly, I say to you, I do not know you.’—Matt 25:11-12 (NKJ).”

questions.question: Drawing on Augustine’s reflection cited in the Eternal State section, how is the loss involved in banishment from the kingdom of God assessed?

options.text: As serious but ultimately comparable to other forms of human suffering
As a kind of symbolic loss that will eventually be reversed
As a loss so great that nothing else that can be conceived could be compared with it
As an unfortunate but morally neutral fate

questions.explanation: After describing being shut out and not known by Christ, the notes quote Augustine: “ ‘To be lost out of the kingdom of God, to be an exile from the c... nceive, could be compared with it.’—Augustine, Enchiridion, 112.”

quizzes.title: Eternal State – Heaven, New Creation, and Practical Hope
quizzes.description: Heaven vs. New Jerusalem, new heavens and new earth, via negativa, and pastoral implications.

questions.question: When introducing the topic, how does the Eternal State outline redirect our emphasis when we talk about “heaven”?

options.text: It urges us to focus mainly on the intermediate state of disembodied souls rather than any future earth.
It says our emphasis should be on the "New Jerusalem" as a purely spiritual realm unrelated to the earth.
It suggests that the biblical emphasis is not on an abstract “heaven” but on New Heavens and a New Earth.
It claims that Scripture focuses almost exclusively on the believer’s present spiritual experience, not on any future place.

questions.explanation: The section opens with the heading: “Heaven: Should the emphasis be on Heaven or on the ‘New Jerusalem’? Scripture points to New Heavens and a New Earth.”

questions.question: True or False: In the New Testament discussion, heaven is described as the habitation of the Father, a place Jesus calls His “Father’s house” with “many rooms.”

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Under “Heaven in the New Testament” the outline says: “Heaven in the New Testament: hundreds of references in the NT. The habitation of the Father (Matt 6:9; John 14:2):” and then quotes, “Our Father, who art in Heaven”—Matt 6:9, and “In my Father’s house are many rooms”—John 14:2.

questions.question: How does the Eternal State section summarize the relationship between the present heaven and the future New Heavens and New Earth?

options.text: The present celestial heaven will be replaced by a purely earthly kingdom, with no connection between them.
The present earth will be abandoned while the celestial heaven remains unchanged forever.
The present celestial heaven and a renewed earth will be brought together in a merging of the two, so that heaven will be a place on earth.
The New Heavens and New Earth are only metaphors for an improved church in this age.

questions.explanation: The outline states: “The New Heavens and the New Earth: The present celestial heaven … [and the renewed earth] … a merging of the two. Finally Heaven will be a place on Earth.”

questions.question: In the “Annihilation or Renovation?” subsection, how is the tension between apparent “annihilation” texts (2 Pet 3:10; Rev 21:1) and “renovation” texts (Matt 19:28; Acts 3:21; Rom 8:19–22) resolved by analogy to the believer’s resurrection body?

options.text: By suggesting that creation will be completely replaced with something unrelated, unlike the believer’s body.
By arguing that the world will be annihilated, whereas the believer’s body is only symbolically raised.
By proposing that our resurrected bodies are fitting analogies: there is both continuity and discontinuity—“dissolved yet transformed.”
By denying that the New Testament ever speaks of renovation at all.

questions.explanation: After listing annihilation and renovation texts, the outline says: “Perhaps our resurrected bodies are fitting analogies for what happens to creation. Both continuity and discontinuity; dissolved yet transformed.”

questions.question: Which of the following correctly matches one of the seven “via negativa” features in Revelation 21 with its explanation in the Eternal State outline?

options.text: No more sea – because large bodies of water are simply impractical for a city.
No more grief – God wipes away every tear, so mourning, crying, and pain are removed as “the former things” pass away.
No more temple – because God will no longer be worshiped in any structured way.
No more needs – because human beings themselves become self-sufficient apart from God’s glory.

questions.explanation: Under “Via negativa” the outline lists: “No more grief (21:4): Based on Isa 25:8-9,” and then quotes: “He will wipe away every tear from their eyes…neither shall there be mourning nor crying nor pain anymore, for the former things have passed away.”—Rev 21:4.

questions.question: True or False: In the “Via negativa” list, “No more wrong desires” is connected to the thirsty being satisfied by the water of life and the cowardly and unbelieving being excluded because they were dominated by evil.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: The outline includes: “No more wrong desires (21:6-8): The thirsty are satisfied by ‘the spring of the water of life’ while the cowardly and unbelieving, etc., are excluded because they were dominated by evil (v 8). Impurity is gone (21:27).”

questions.question: How does the Eternal State material describe the shift from Genesis to Revelation when talking about the New Jerusalem?

options.text: It says that paradise is simply a return to Genesis, repeating the garden without any development.
It describes the New Jerusalem as a purely symbolic city that has no connection to the Eden narrative.
It says, “Paradise is not simply a return to Genesis. ‘What started as a garden ends as a metropolis.’”
It claims that the garden of Eden will be rebuilt exactly as before, with no city imagery at all.

questions.explanation: Under “The New Jerusalem (Rev 21-22)” we read: “Paradise is not simply a return to Genesis. ‘What started as a garden ends as a metropolis.’”

questions.question: What is the significance of there being “no more temple” in the New Jerusalem, according to the Eternal State outline?

options.text: It means worship and God’s presence are no longer central in the eternal state.
It is remarkable because the original Jerusalem was defined by its temple, but in the New Jerusalem God and the Lamb themselves are the temple.
It indicates that there will be no place set apart for God at all.
It shows that the Old Testament temple promises fail in the end.

questions.explanation: The outline lists: “No more temple (21:22): Remarkable, since this is the unique feature of the original Jerusalem,” and then quotes: “And I saw no temple in the city, for its temple is the Lord God the Almighty and the Lamb.”—Rev. 21:22.

questions.question: True or False: Under the practical questions from Hammett, the Eternal State material affirms that in heaven we will rest, worship, serve, and begin a never-ending journey into the knowledge of God.

options.text: True
False

questions.explanation: Under “Questions about the New Heavens and the New Earth (Hammett, 158)” it asks, “What will we do in Heaven?” and answers: “We will rest (Rev. 14:13)… We will worship (Rev. 15:2-4); We will serve (Rev. 22:3)… We will begin a never-ending journey into the knowledge of God.”

questions.question: In the final “Summing up” section, what is identified as the ultimate goal toward which the eternal state points?

options.text: That every creature will merge into an impersonal divine essence.
That this present world will prove to be the best of all possible worlds so that no change is needed.
That human beings will finally outgrow the need for God and rule independently.
That “all things [are] united in Jesus Christ,” in line with Ephesians 1:9–10.

questions.explanation: The concluding questions ask, “What is the goal? All things united in Jesus Christ,” followed by Ephesians 1:9–10: “He set it all out before us in Christ, a long-range plan in which everything would be brought together and summed up in him, everything in deepest heaven, everything on planet earth.”
